title: bayeux tapestrys 960 year old mistakes uncovered amateur embroiderer
story: A soldier with two left hands. A sailor with no facial features. A courtier with one red leg and one white.Nightmarish as these tableaux might sound, they derive not from a horror film but from the Bayeux Tapestry. Long regarded as one of the most important records of English history, the tapestry turns out to be riddled with errors.And these errors go beyond the famously ambiguous death of King Harold, who might be the soldier struck in the eye by an arrow, but who might also be the inidual slashed by a cavalryman’s sword and trampled underfoot.Mia Hansson, an amateur embroiderer from Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, is six years into her project of making a full-size replica of the tapestry. The original, of course, is 230ft in length and tells the story of the Norman conquest of England, culminating in the Battle of Hastings and – spoiler alert – the victory of William the Conqueror.Thought to date to the 11th century, the tapestry has previously been hailed as “one of the supreme achievements of the Norman Romanesque” by Sylvette Lemagnen, author of the 2005 book La Tapisserie de Bayeux. Its status assured, Lemagnen says, by its “exceptional length, the harmony and freshness of its colours, its exquisite workmanship, and the genius of its guiding spirit.”Perhaps it is time to dock a few marks from this mainstay of British history teaching. Over the six years in which she has been painstakingly copying the tapestry, Ms Hansson has identified at least 15 mistakes in the original.They begin with the sailor, who has a rope running across the void where his face should be. They continue with a mounted soldier whose chainmail is rounded in the portion above his waist and square beneath it – a discrepancy that Ms Hansson ascribes to the tapestry being embroidered by two people at once. The errors continue with the men carrying the coffin of Edward the Confessor – look closely and you will see that there aren’t enough legs to go round.Given that Ms Hansson still has roughly another six years’ worth of work to go, we can safely forecast that more errors will emerge.But she is not amending them, despite her professional instinct – Ms Hansson, 47, is a trained primary school teacher – to correct. She is reproducing the tapestry, she says, “as faithfully as I can, because they did an enormous job. This is a masterpiece, this embroidery, and who am I to come and correct what they’ve done? I’m trying to honour it, warts and all.”That said, the errors can be frustrating. “This is going to turn my hair grey,” she said. “I’m working on a piece now where the back leg of a horse is just simply wrong.“There’s everything wrong about it and I have to copy that and it’s doing my head in.”Ms Hansson has also turned the tapestry into a colouring book. She will display the unfinished replica tapestry at St Peter’s Church Hall in Wisbech on April 12.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine crisis: Skirmish near border raises fear of false flag attackBritons didn’t know what they were doing when they backed Brexit, says European ParliamentSydney shark attack victim named as British expat Simon NellistStorm Dudley: Travel chaos and thousands left without power - as even stronger Storm Eunice nearsThursday morning news briefing: Putin &#39could drag out crisis&#39Rust shooting: Animated video shows moment Alec Baldwin killed Halyna Hutchins on setMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: eden project creator sir tim smit criticises cornish people
story: As the creator of the Eden Project, Sir Tim Smit has had a transformative effect on Cornwall, bringing worldwide attention, jobs and a much-needed economic boost.But no good turn goes unpunished, it seems, particularly in a county where outsiders like Dutch-born Sir Tim are insultingly labelled “grockles” by some natives.For 20 years, Sir Tim has bitten his tongue as critics have railed against change, but he has finally let rip with an extraordinary takedown of locals who obsess about their “mums’ pasties” and romanticise “good old days” that never existed.In an expletive-laden rant, Sir Tim, who grew up in Sussex, accused Cornish people of defining their lives “in terms of what you don’t like” and of attacking entrepreneurs like Rick Stein who had helped rejuvenate their county.He told The Reason Why podcast: “One of the problems in Cornwall is, if you say anything – if you’re not Cornish – and you say anything about it, they say you’re an arrogant so-and-so speaking for the Cornish.“You feel, and I don’t, but you feel like saying ‘well if you were a bit more f- - -ing articulate you could speak up for yourself but you haven’t’.“You’ve all got mums who made the best pasties in the world and it’s fantastic and it’s fabulous, and you talk about the good old days, and the good old days never were the good old days.“They’ve been bad for about 70 years – and they’ve been bad because of t- - - - - s like you.”Sir Tim, 67, opened the Eden Project in 2000 after transforming an old clay pit near St Austell into a unique world of interlinking domes housing exotic plants from around the world. It attracts more than a million visitors each year and is reported to have contributed more than £1billion to the Cornish economy.Not everyone has welcomed the influx of visitors and cash, but Sir Tim said it was time they came up with their own ideas for taking the county forward rather than simply directing anger at those who are doing it for them.“His foundation was the fishermen of Padstow and him being a chef of fish.“He is personally quite anxious about being seen as a spokesman for Cornwall because he knows you get bricks thrown at you for saying you speak for anybody here.”Malcolm Bell, chief executive of the tourism body Visit Cornwall, said: “I suppose my reaction is I am a bit offended. The Cornish people are wonderfully warm and welcoming. It is regrettable because we are a community, we are a proud community. We know there are some strong views that most of us maybe don’t agree with and it does polarise people.“My view very simply is if you can’t say anything nice, don’t say anything at all.”On Wednesday, Sir Tim apologised for the comments. In a statement, he said: “I’m sorry that some of the comments I made in the podcast have caused offence. “I hope that when people listen to the whole piece they will realise that I was speaking in the context of defending my friend Rick Stein and my strongest words were directed at people who seek to damn him for making Cornwall attractive to outsiders.“I wasn’t intending to comment on Cornish people as a whole, rather some of those who would tell you that the past was better than now when the truth is different it was not.“Cornwall has been my home for more than 30 years and I don’t want  a few harsh words on my part to damage the many friendships I’ve made in a place I love.  “My comments in the round are extremely pro-Cornwall and the rightness of anger at the neglect of this special place  - and an encouragement not to attack the wrong targets.”The podcast was hosted by Cornish actor and musician Seamus Carer, who said: “I’ve tried to make a balanced, nuanced piece of journalism about Cornwall, from the point of view of someone who grew up and still lives here. With that in mind, I’m extremely grateful to Tim for giving me his time and opinions.“I’m a big fan of empathy, so can see where Tim’s coming from whilst also understanding the anger that some listeners have voiced. It’s good to remember that Tim’s made big things happen in Cornwall, which many people have benefited from. He’s a canny businessman, with a confident style. He’s always been very supportive of my work and is a family friend.“However, I’m aware that some people feel distrust and animosity towards him, hence why he was such an important figure to interview. The overall aim of the podcast was to look at issues in contemporary Cornwall and to try to understand both sides of the argument. There’s no simple answer to any of it, but having dialogue and listening is certainly a good start. That’s all I tried to do.”More from NewsBritons didn’t know what they were doing when they backed Brexit, says European ParliamentRussia-Ukraine crisis: Skirmish near border raises fear of false flag attackSydney shark attack victim named as British expat Simon NellistStorm Dudley: Travel chaos and thousands left without power - as even stronger Storm Eunice nearsThursday morning news briefing: Putin &#39could drag out crisis&#39Rust shooting: Animated video shows moment Alec Baldwin killed Halyna Hutchins on setMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: hms queen elizabeth inside aircraft carrier royal navy flagship
story: The yellow-helmeted flight deck officer leans into a 40-knot wind and raises a small green flag in his right hand. I crouch behind him, clutching my robust but battered high-def camera. A few feet away, a snarling F-35B Lightning Stealth Fighter, sleek as a shark and every bit as lethal, prepares to launch into the steel-grey skies of the eastern Mediterranean.On the bridge, the navigators steer directly into the wind. ‘Steady on designated flying course, one-one-zero,’ says the officer of the watch.  ‘Steady on one-one-zero, sir,’ confirms the helmsman.The F-35B needs plenty of headwind to get airborne. The aircraft has a run-up of only 350 feet to the curved ‘ski-jump’, from which it will make its final leap skywards. Inside the glass-encased flight control tower behind us, the vessel’s Commander Air, Ed Phillips, aka ‘Wings’, looks up and down the massive flight deck and, when satisfied all is clear, gives a short sharp order:All eyes turn to the green flag held aloft and rippling in the wind. Probably worth no more than a couple of quid, it is brought down to the ground with a dramatic flourish the signal for the F-35B, worth well over £100 million, to get airborne.I brace myself for the immense power about to be unleashed. I’ve witnessed this many times and know what to expect. It’ll be exhilarating, for sure, but also terrifying and probably painful. I’m determined to capture on film a spectacular close-up of a launch as near to the aircraft as possible, but the timing is critical and so far I’ve manifestly failed to pull it off.The searing blast from the rear jet nozzle has always blown me off my feet and sent me sprawling. I have the bruises and cuts to show for it and God knows how much skin I’ve now invested in the roughened, diamond-hard surface of the flight deck. But I still don’t have the footage I want. This time, two hefty sailors are ready to hold me down, or at least try to. My fear is that no amount of muscle power will be a match for the explosive thrust of what is essentially a horizontal rocket.The pilot releases the brakes and opens the throttle. The Pratt &amp Whitney afterburning, turbofan engine raises its pitch to a terrifying scream as the aircraft surges forward. I clench my teeth, tense my muscles and, with my heart pounding in my ears, bear hug the camera in a semi-stable position. But how long can I hold on? Four vice-like hands press down on my hunched shoulders.It’s June 2021 and I’ve joined the ship’s company of HMS Queen Elizabeth for her first operational deployment. We are some weeks into a seven-month voyage to the South China Sea, not on exercise but, locked, loaded and ready for action, should it become necessary.The new carrier and fleet flagship, together with eight escorts (destroyers, frigates, supply ships and a submarine) comprise Carrier Strike Group 21 (CSG21) – the most powerful naval force to leave the UK in a generation. Prior to our transit through the Suez Canal and the Red Sea, on our way to the Pacific and the disputed waters of the South China Sea, the ship has been launching waves of jets on Operation Shader – in support of land forces in the fight against Islamic State in Syria. But this has prompted a reaction from the Russians. They consider this part of the Med their own backyard and are intent on letting the QE and her escorts know they’re not welcome here. But the QE is the new dog on the block and she’s here to mark her own territory, not with a wag of the tail but a snarl.Today’s launch of the F-35s, therefore, is not to attack IS but to ward off Russian warplanes attempting to overfly us. Pilots, drawn from the Fleet Air Arm, RAF and US Marine Corps, have been scrambling all day, sometimes in rapid two-minute intervals, to intercept ‘red bandits’ and escort them away at a safe range.The Russians, apart from wanting to goad the Royal Navy, are desperate to get a closer look at the QE, the most advanced aircraft carrier in the world, and also test the Task Group’s reaction procedures – not only in the air but also on the surface, with their warships, and underwater with their submarines. The QE’s Anti-Submarine Warfare Merlin Mk2 helicopters from 820 Naval Air Squadron are on constant patrol in order to monitor subsurface incursions and react accordingly. Nobody has actually opened fire, but there’s a lot of posturing and tactical lip-curling. If this is the start of a new Cold War, nobody is in doubt that things could heat up very quickly. The QE’s magazines are bursting with bombs, bullets and missiles of all descriptions and capabilities, as you’d expect on a warship that is now Britain’s main conventional strategic deterrent.Commodore Steve Moorhouse, leading CSG21, knows that Britain’s potential adversaries, the Russians and Chinese, will prod and poke his Task Group at every opportunity. ‘They want to see what we’re made of,’ he freely admits. ‘And I’m happy to show them, but professionally, in a spirit of confidence, not confrontation.’ Moorhouse is a steely commander but also a diplomat by default. After all, HMS Queen Elizabeth, a chunk of British sovereign territory, is part warship, part floating embassy. As the embodiment of ‘Global Britain’, her charge is to deliver ‘power projection’ on behalf of the nation: on the one hand that means hard-edged, lethal warfare on the other it’s about soft, political persuasion through deterrence, as well as overt support for allies around the world.Friends and foes alike will be watching this deployment with keen interest and I’m here to capture it on film for a forthcoming BBC TV series. But this isn’t the first time I’ve filmed HMS Queen Elizabeth. That was back in 2009, when I witnessed Princess Anne cutting the ship’s first steel at Govan shipyard in Glasgow. This was not so much the birth of Britain’s biggest-ever warship – more like her conception – and I was struck by the enormity of the occasion.  Sir Jonathon Band, the First Sea Lord at the time, spoke with passion to the audience and assembled media. The Queen Elizabeth Class of aircraft carrier, comprising HMS Queen Elizabeth, with HMS Prince of Wales to follow, would, he explained, ‘provide Britain with the means to deliver air power from the sea, wherever and whenever required, and in a stronger and more decisive form than ever before’. They will also, he added, ‘be the centrepiece of Britain’s military capability for many years to come’.The construction of HMS Queen Elizabeth and her sister ship meant a complete reinvention of the Royal Navy but, despite Sir Jonathon’s upbeat messaging, it was to prove a painful and long-drawn-out process. Our active carriers at the time, Ark Royal, Illustrious and Invincible, were about to be axed in the 2010 Strategic Defence and Security Review and with them the Navy’s Harrier squadron – its entire naval fixed-wing capability. Already, naysayers and vocal critics were provoking a heated debate over the pros and cons of a carrier-centric Navy, and whether there’d be enough escort ships to protect the carriers while at sea or sufficient sailors to man them – each would be three times the size of the Invincible Class carriers.General Sir Peter Wall, former head of the British Army, described the decision to build the new carriers as no more than a ‘vanity project’ that ‘lacked credibility’ and which could be seen to have ‘skewed the UK’s conventional defence effort to a damaging degree’. Max Hastings, ever the provocateur, suggested the new warships represented delusions of grandeur for a Navy in decline. Other denigrators were quick to point out that a large carrier is a big target – especially for the new generation of hypersonic missiles that the Chinese call ‘carrier killers’.Russia inevitably chimed in with some of its own political trash talk: ‘Just make sure you keep your new carrier away from Moscow’s warships or they’ll send it to the bottom of the sea.’Military hardware is an emotive subject, especially in the context of huge capital expenditure that might otherwise be spent on housing, welfare or the NHS, but £6 billion for two vessels (albeit a near doubling of the original budget) is modest compared to the eye-watering price tag of USS Gerald R. Ford, an American super-carrier of similar proportions which cost more than $13 billion (and which, according to the Pentagon, ‘has yet to demonstrate it can effectively defend itself from anti-ship missiles and other threats’).The glossy brochure issued by a conglomerate of shipbuilders known as the Aircraft Carrier Alliance certainly suggested that Britain was getting its money’s worth. At 65,000 tonnes, HMS Queen Elizabeth and HMS Prince of Wales would not only be the biggest warships ever built for the Royal Navy, but also the most powerful and advanced in terms of military technology and stealth capabilities – especially when married eventually to the state-of-the-art F-35B Lightning jet fighter.The sales pitch for the super-carriers came with a staggering array of facts and figures. The ships, it claimed, would be so highly automated they’d require only ‘lean-manned’ crews – less than 1,000 per ship, without aircrew. That’s broadly one fifth the size of an American crew on a similar-sized ship. They’d each have a four-acre flight deck, the size of three and a half football fields, nine decks and a hangar big enough to fit two Type 23 frigates side by side. Each carrier would have two propellers weighing 33 tonnes – exerting the same thrust as 50 high-speed trains and producing a maximum speed in excess of 27 knots (31mph). The six engines (two mighty gas turbines and four diesels) would produce enough energy to power a city the size of Swindon the electrical cabling and wiring would stretch six times round the world the ship, weighing the same as 35,000 family cars, would carry enough fuel to take those cars to the moon and back a dozen times… and on it went.The statistics were mind-boggling, but one thing was for sure: the challenge of building the first of these ships – the nine-decked HMS Queen Elizabeth – manning her, taking her to sea and getting her battle-ready was going to be a compelling story, as I learnt while following her construction in seven shipyards around the UK, culminating in her final assembly at Rosyth in Fife, like some gargantuan Lego toy. But, engineering aside, I knew that her real story would reside in the sailors yet to arrive the men and women who would breathe life into the country’s first super-carrier.  Foremost among them was Jerry Kyd, the ship’s first seagoing captain. I encountered him on the day he arrived in Rosyth in May 2016, as he addressed a fledgling ship’s company of just 456 sailors standing in front of their ship, still an inert hulk without propellers and dead in the water.‘The world’s a frisky place at the moment,’ he said. ‘And we have to be ready to respond to threats which I think are coming sooner rather than later.’ Kyd glanced towards their future home, encased in scaffolding. ‘HMS Queen Elizabeth, as big and sophisticated as she might be, is really just a huge metal box, full of pipes, wires, gadgetry and computer terminals. She’s missing one vital ingredient…’ He paused dramatically. ‘Without the flesh, blood, muscle and hearts of you, my sailors, that ship is just a robot. You, not the ship, are the most important resource at my disposal.’It was nearly a year before the QE was ready for her first sea trials. As a ‘new build’, there were bound to be problems. On the eve of our departure for the North Sea, Captain Kyd warned that there would be emergencies: ‘We’ll have floods, we’ll have fires. And casualties too. That’s the nature of this business.’For the best part of two months the ship was put through her paces off the coast of Scotland, where I joined them. The first aircraft, a Merlin helicopter, was landed on the flight deck within four days as the ship’s company got used to their largely subterranean existence deep in the belly of the beast. I watched with amazement as the sailors, many of them straight out of training, transformed the massive grey hulk not only into a working warship but a home from home. The QE was fast becoming a vibrant floating city and, with 23 nations represented from across the Commonwealth, all human life was here. My first challenge, however, was to learn my way round a ship longer than the Houses of Parliament and taller than Nelson’s Column and so gigantic that it boasted five kilometres of passageways and 3,200 compartments.Apart from a serious issue with a cracked thrust block that held one of the drive shafts in place, all went as well as could be expected. As Jerry Kyd foretold, there were plenty of fires and floods as the ship was pushed to breaking point so that her technical and seagoing limits could be identified. There were ‘casualties’ too, but thankfully only minor ones – the worst being cracked teeth and broken fingers. Sea trials completed, we finally entered Portsmouth dockyard, the ship’s designated home port, and within months the QE was officially commissioned by the Queen.After a period of maintenance, the ship set off for the next vital stage of her trials off the eastern seaboard of the US. Within hours of leaving Portsmouth we became aware of an ominous presence – a Russian Federation frigate called Admiral Makarov had closed to within two miles of our position. A highly capable warship armed with Kalibr long-range cruise missiles, the Makarov was in transit from the Baltic to Sevastopol on the Black Sea. While officially permitted to route through the English Channel she had clearly erted her course to have a closer look at our ship.  A few days later, just before starting our transatlantic crossing, we were suddenly erted into the Irish Sea to help chase off a Russian submarine spotted in British territorial waters. There was an increasing concern, as there still is, that Russians could be sussing out British underwater power and communication cabling – an obvious target for a potential enemy.  The Russian sub made a run for it as soon as we got close. Even before the QE had become operational the writing was on the wall and it was written very clearly in Cyrillic script. A sign of things to come (and indeed I write this as the world tries to second-guess Russian designs on Ukraine).Following this brief ersion we progressed across the Atlantic and the next dramatic event I witnessed was the ship’s first-ever run ashore in a foreign port, which didn’t go entirely to plan. In Mayport, Florida, after a night of heavy drinking, four sailors from the QE and two from our escort frigate, HMS Monmouth, were arrested for a range of alcohol-related offences including jaywalking, fighting and resisting arrest. Despite making headlines on both sides of the Atlantic, the episode was soon forgotten and at least part of the blame was attached to overzealous policing.  Captain Kyd, a pragmatist, reckoned that a night in jail was punishment enough for sailors letting off steam. ‘The question we have to ask ourselves,’ Kyd told his commanders, ‘is what sort of sailor would we want to go to war with? The automaton who obeys every rule, plays it safe and never takes chances? Or the free spirit who pushes his luck and breaks the odd rule?’    Kyd quickly refocused on the job in hand – namely to see an F-35B Lightning jet land on the ship’s flight deck for the first time. Helicopters were one thing, but a fighter jet that lands vertically using immense downward thrust from its enormous engine was quite another. Commander Nathan Gray, the Navy’s top test pilot, was the first to attempt a landing. It went without a hitch, although many questions remained about safety margins before the flight deck and aircraft could be handed over to front-line combat pilots. Two months of continuous, painstaking testing in all weathers, including a full-blown hurricane, gradually provided the answers. Gray, despite a few near misses, was satisfied that he and his colleagues had done all they could to ready the ship and aircraft for action.  And so to the present. Here I am aboard the QE once again – no longer on sea trials, but busy arm-wrestling the Russians, and before long she’ll be playing cat-and-mouse with the Chinese in the South China Sea. This is the acid test, with much at stake. The Prime Minister has declared he wants the Royal Navy to be the most powerful and influential in Europe by the end of the decade. CSG21 is the first step to achieving that ambition and proving that the new aircraft carrier is no white elephant but an effective instrument of government as well as an iconic symbol of nation.  Great adventure beckons and, once again, all life is here – a much expanded ship’s company of 1,650 men and women. Yes, there are the aviators yes, there are the seafarers yes, there are the marine engineers. But there are so many others: stewards, chefs, medics, gunners, aircraft handlers, writers, warfare specialists, physical trainers and intelligence officers. There is even a specialist chocolatier and, maybe because of him, a dedicated dentist and dental hygienist.‘Bleeding frozen chips!’ shouts Ronnie Lambert, an Essex boy, born and bred. ‘They want 10 more boxes in the main galley and they’re all at the back of the frickin’ fridge.’‘Well, get in there and pull ’em out,’ laughs fellow storeman Aaron Mackin. ‘It’s yer bleedin’ job.’‘Well, I’m transferring to aviation! Them boys have it easy up there. All sunshine and sea.’    The F-35B, accelerating from a standing start, rattles my bones. The heavyset sailors push down hard on my prone body as I attempt to point the camera in the right direction. The sailors are now lying on top of me – the jet stream strikes and skittles us. I roll across the deck, trying to protect my camera. Did I capture the moment of take off? I will check as soon as I can. Lying on my back I look up to see five British F-35s close in on three Russian MiGs.There will be more Russian warplanes soon. They’ll keep coming, but at least we know one thing: we have chips to go with our fish tonight. Must be a Friday.More from NewsStorm Dudley: Travel chaos and thousands left without power - as even stronger Storm Eunice nearsBritons didn’t know what they were doing when they backed Brexit, says European ParliamentRussia-Ukraine crisis: Skirmish near border raises fear of false flag attackSydney shark attack victim named as British expat Simon NellistThursday morning news briefing: Putin &#39could drag out crisis&#39Rust shooting: Animated video shows moment Alec Baldwin killed Halyna Hutchins on setMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: met launches cash for honours investigation prince charless
story: Prince Charles has said he is willing to speak to detectives after Scotland Yard announced it had launched a criminal investigation into an alleged cash for honours scandal involving one of his closest confidants.The politan Police is examining claims that Michael Fawcett, his former right-hand man, had worked with fixers to secure a CBE for the Saudi billionaire Mahfouz Marei Mubarak bin Mahfouz, who had given more than £1.5 million to the Prince’s Foundation charity.The Prince of Wales, who presented Mr Mahfouz with the honorary title at a private ceremony at Buckingham Palace in 2016, has denied any knowledge of the alleged deal.Royal sources have said Prince Charles is willing to speak to police in order to help with the investigation.“There has been no request for help from the police so far, but if he is asked to help he will of course do so,” the source said. A Clarence House spokesman said: “The Prince of Wales had no knowledge of the alleged offer of honours or British citizenship on the basis of donation to his charities.”Scotland Yard confirmed it had launched a criminal investigation into the allegations, which first appeared in the media last year.The Prince's Foundation is an educational charity established in 1986 which brings together a number of projects and causes that Prince Charles is passionate about.The allegations centered around claims that Mr Mahfouz, who denies any wrongdoing, donated large sums to restoration projects of particular interest to Prince Charles.Mr Fawcett - who has been a close aide to the Prince for more than 40-years - resigned as the chief executive of the Prince’s Foundation charity in the wake of the allegations.Detectives liaised with the officials from the Prince’s Foundation after Norman Baker, the former Liberal Democrat MP, made a formal complaint to Scotland Yard.In December, the Prince’s Foundation published the findings of its own investigation into the allegations, which stated there was some evidence of communication between the CEO and fixers regarding honorary nominations for a donor between 2014-18.But the report stated it had found no evidence that the charity’s trustees were aware of this.The police investigation is being led by the Met's Special Enquiry Team, the same unit that is in charge of the Partygate investigation.A Scotland Yard spokesman said: The politan Police Service has launched an investigation into allegations of offences under the Honours (Prevention of Abuses) Act 1925.The decision follows an assessment of a September 2021 letter. This related to media reporting alleging offers of help were made to secure honours and citizenship for a Saudi national.The Special Enquiry Team has conducted the assessment process which has included contacting those believed to hold relevant information.Officers liaised with The Prince’s Foundation about the findings of an independent investigation into fundraising practices. The Foundation provided a number of relevant documents.These documents were reviewed alongside existing information. The assessment determined an investigation will commence. There have been no arrests or interviews under caution.A spokesperson for The Prince's Foundation said: It would be inappropriate to comment on an ongoing investigation.More from NewsBritons didn’t know what they were doing when they backed Brexit, says European ParliamentRussia-Ukraine crisis: Skirmish near border raises fear of false flag attackSydney shark attack victim named as British expat Simon NellistStorm Dudley: Travel chaos and thousands left without power - as even stronger Storm Eunice nearsThursday morning news briefing: Putin &#39could drag out crisis&#39Rust shooting: Animated video shows moment Alec Baldwin killed Halyna Hutchins on setMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: relocate england scots vote independence says head major defence
story: The head of a major defence firm has warned his company could relocate to England if Scots were to vote for independence.David Lockwood, the chief executive of Babcock, said its huge fabrication yard at Rosyth could move south within three years if the firm was made to feel unwelcome after a referendum.Unionists said the intervention showed that major employers would desert the country if Nicola Sturgeon delivers on her plan of winning a referendum next year.Mr Lockwood, speaking to The Courier after Boris Johnson visited Rosyth in Fife this week, said Babcock could “manage” the break up of the UK but suggested this could involve relocation.Almost 800 skilled engineers are employed at the site, one of the largest waterside manufacturing and repair facilities in the UK.“I think in reality there will be plenty of warning if the vote were in favour of independence,” Mr Lockwood said.“There would then be a negotiation period and at the end of the negotiation period there would be an implementation period. So I don’t think there is anything that we can’t manage as a company.”He added: “If we had to replicate this in England because we were told we weren’t welcome here – which I think would be a bad mistake for Scotland – but if that were the decision, we can replicate this in three years, and the time window of negotiations is longer than that. It’s not ideal but it is manageable.”SNP figures responded by insisting that Babcock would be welcome in an independent Scotland. However elements within the independence movement, including the Scottish Greens who are in a coalition government with the SNP, have condemned Scottish-based defence firms as “arms dealers who profit from delivering death, destruction and misery”.Ms Sturgeon has insisted she intends to hold a new vote on independence by next year, although there are major doubts over whether she will be able to deliver.However, Mr Lockwood also warned that the ongoing constitutional debate alone was putting firms off investing in Scotland.“I think if you are already here it is manageable,” he said. “But I think it is a slightly different question if you weren’t here, does it affect your decision?“I am aware of people who are … it is a question they ask when they are making a decision where to base themselves.”Douglas Chapman, the SNP MP for Dunfermline and West Fife, said he was “disappointed” with Mr Lockwood’s remarks. “As the local MP I have consistently supported Babcock and the Rosyth workforce,” he said. “They make a very valuable and significant contribution to our economy. “They operate and are welcomed in many independent countries globally. An independent Scotland will be no different.”Stewart McDonald, the SNP defence spokesman, said the firm was “not just welcome, but vital”.He added: “Babcock is not just an important employer, but would play a crucial role in an independent Scotland’s defence capability.”More from NewsStorm Dudley: Travel chaos and thousands left without power - as even stronger Storm Eunice nearsBritons didn’t know what they were doing when they backed Brexit, says European ParliamentRussia-Ukraine crisis: Skirmish near border raises fear of false flag attackSydney shark attack victim named as British expat Simon NellistThursday morning news briefing: Putin &#39could drag out crisis&#39Rust shooting: Animated video shows moment Alec Baldwin killed Halyna Hutchins on setMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: secrets number 10 front door
story: As with so much to do with 10 Downing Street right now, establishing the facts about its famous front door isn’t always as straightforward. A  reader wrote a Letter to the Editor this week, to correct no less an eminence than Sandi Toksvig on the question of why the zero on the threshold to the Prime Minister’s residence is skew-whiff.On the BBC’s brainbox television show, QI, Toksvig had explained that the 37-degree tilt to the left on the numeral ‘0’ in question “had always been” that way since what had hitherto been 5 Downing Street was redesignated 10 Downing Street in 1779.  But the letter’s author, Malvern Harper, who had trained as a sign writer in the 1960s, recalled that his tutor had told him the slant was because the number ‘0’ was actually a capitalised letter ‘O’ in the same unusual typography used on Emperor Trajan’s Column in Rome in AD113.Both explanations can be found in the many histories of Downing Street written since Sir Robert Walpole took up residence there in 1732 at the invitation of George II. And there is even a variation that suggests the official Department of Works, as a result of another round of austerity which coincided with the renovation of Numbers 10, 11 and 12 in the early 1960s, had simply run out of ‘0’s. In the spirit of make do and mend, they substituted a spare Trajan ‘O’ as the next best thing.Which account is right? Even as one who has experienced that frisson – as if a very small footnote in history – of stepping over the threshold, I’ve no idea. But I can report some other secrets that the Downing Street door hides in plain sight. The original six-panel Georgian door, made of black oak, was installed in 1772 when Lord North was Prime Minister, as part of extensive renovations that saw three Downing Street properties knocked into one of suitable grandeur. Its 1991 replacement is made of black gloss-finish steel, installed for added security after an IRA attack, when John Major was PM, saw a mortar land in Number 10’s back garden. (When it needs maintenance, it has an equally robust twin that holds the fort.)If you can see past the press pack regularly gathered outside, the eagle-eyed will notice that there is no lock in which to put a key, and no handle. This is a door than can only be opened from the inside, where – because the brass door bell to its right is for decorative purposes only – a security guard is on duty 247, watching security cameras so it can swing open as if by magic on cue to allow in prime ministers, ministers, monarchs and assorted visiting dignitaries.  Or, on occasion, fail to open: as once when the Blair family were briefly left stranded on the doorstep, or worse in 2016 when US Secretary of State, John Kerry, came for his first meeting with Theresa May and walked straight into the door.  For those wanting to find a more discreet way into 10 Downing Street – and I will leave it to your imagination why that might be necessary – there is a back door, which does boast its own keyhole. If only they could train Larry the resident Downing Street cat to make use of it.There is something solid, serious and stately about today's glossy black door. Back in 1908, however, Herbert Asquith decreed – at the instigation, it is said, of his wife, the celebrated wit and socialite, Margot – that black was passé. Instead it was given a lick of what historical paint consultants have suggested was either Brunswick Green or Bronze Green, as popular then with those in the know as gold wallpaper is today.  The experiment didn’t last. Asquith's successor, David Lloyd George, known for his colourful turn of phrase and private life, proved to be more sober and traditional when it came to picking paint.If you have ever wondered why those delivering petitions to the Prime Minister can’t just slip their bundle of papers through the shiny brass letter box, there is an easy answer. Despite appearances, it is not a letter-box at all, but a shiny brass plate simply made to look like one (for security purposes) inscribed with the words First Lord of the Treasury. When Sir Robert Walpole took on the house in 1735, that was his official title, though he was de facto Prime Minister. All his successors since 1905 have held both offices simultaneously. The original lion’s head door-furniture was made of cast iron, the essential ingredient of the Industrial Revolution that began in Britain. At the outset of the First World War, soldiers about to depart for the trenches are reported to have walked up Downing Street to touch the knocker for good luck. During the 1960 renovations it was replaced by a brass lion's head painted black with Downing Street now out of bounds to the casual passer-by, it is in no immediate danger of being rubbed off.There are other alternatives at hand. Close by is the original door, on display in the Churchill War Rooms, or else wander down Whitehall, onto the Strand and turn into Adam Street, where a near identical front door, with similar frame and façade around it, is available free of charge at Number 10. But position yourself carefully for maximum authenticity. title: no vladimir putin hasnt humiliated west
story: Only in the fantasy world that is Vladimir Putin’s Russia could the Kremlin seriously believe that the military stand-off over Ukraine has resulted in a humiliating defeat for the West. Mr Putin has deliberately provoked the Ukraine crisis with the aim of forcing the West to make painful concessions, such as denying Kyiv the opportunity to join Nato or withdrawing its military hardware from Eastern and central Europe.Yet, while the willingness of some Western leaders to maintain a firm line has, at times, been open to question, one of the more refreshing outcomes of the crisis is that the Western alliance has held firm. While French President Emmanuel Macron has shown an alarming willingness to undermine Ukraine’s sovereignty, and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz seems willing to rule out any future possibility of Ukraine joining Nato, the bottom line remains that, to date, no meaningful concessions have been made to Mr Putin on either issue. Instead, the Western alliance continues to discuss ways of crippling the Russian economy if Mr Putin is foolhardy enough to activate his invasion plans, demonstrating a level of resolve that has caught many off guard.The refusal to budge on Nato’s right to choose which nations can and cannot apply to join has certainly placed Mr Putin in a quandary, and may well explain why Moscow’s much-vaunted march on Kyiv – which US intelligence agencies had predicted would most likely take place yesterday morning – has yet to materialise.With an estimated 130,000-strong Russian battle group still camped on the Ukrainian border, such an eventuality cannot be discounted, and British security officials, together with their counterparts in the US and Europe, remain convinced that the Russian leader’s ultimate goal is to achieve regime change in Ukraine through military force. None the less, following the Russian defence ministry’s decision to release videos earlier this week of heavy armour being redeployed to barracks, hopes are rising that all-out conflict may yet be averted.For Mr Putin, who has spent much of the past few months stoking the flames of his latest confrontation with the West, the prospect of the crisis being resolved without him achieving any of his stated goals will be hard to accept. The Kremlin’s frustration that events are not moving in the right direction certainly helps to explain Moscow’s almost hysterical reaction earlier this week when Washington’s predictions of a looming Russian invasion failed to materialise.“They were humiliated and defeated without a single shot,” boasted Russian foreign ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova, adding that Russia’s failure to launch its invasion according to the CIA’s precise timetable “will go down in history as the day when Western war propaganda failed”.It still remains to be seen whether the West has badly misjudged Mr Putin’s intentions towards Ukraine, with the Biden administration continuing to warn that an invasion “remains distinctly possible”, and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky confirming that Kyiv has yet to detect any meaningful sign of a Russian withdrawal.Keeping everyone guessing is very much how Mr Putin likes to conduct business, so that not even trusted aides like Sergey Lavrov, his veteran foreign minister, can know with any certainty their leader’s next move. And if Mr Putin can keep his key Kremlin confidantes in the dark, then what chance do his Western adversaries have of ining his objectives?Yet, for all his mind games, Mr Putin’s prospects of achieving any tangible political gains from the Ukraine crisis grow more remote by the day, irrespective of the narrative the Kremlin’s “fake news” machine seeks to conjure up.The Russian leader will look weak and inept if he pulls back from a full-scale invasion without obtaining any guarantees from Nato on Ukraine, or winning concessions from the alliance on its future military dispositions in eastern Europe. Furthermore, his aggressive stance towards Ukraine has forged a new unity of purpose within the alliance that has been sadly lacking since the fiasco of last summer’s withdrawal from Afghanistan. Mr Putin’s bellicose conduct on Europe’s doorstep has resulted in a significant uplift in defence spending among many member states, while previously neutral states such as Sweden and Finland are now giving serious consideration to applying for membership.If, by contrast, Mr Putin does press ahead with the invasion, he is unlikely to achieve a clear-cut victory. There is, for example, a growing consensus within Western security circles that the Kremlin has seriously underestimated the likelihood of Ukrainians launching a long and bloody resistance campaign, one that could ultimately prove very costly for Moscow.So, far from achieving a humiliating defeat of the West, as the Kremlin propaganda machine would have us believe, it is Mr Putin who has most to lose, whether he decides to invade or not.More from NewsBritons didn’t know what they were doing when they backed Brexit, says European ParliamentRussia-Ukraine crisis: Skirmish near border raises fear of false flag attackSydney shark attack victim named as British expat Simon NellistStorm Dudley: Travel chaos and thousands left without power - as even stronger Storm Eunice nearsThursday morning news briefing: Putin &#39could drag out crisis&#39Rust shooting: Animated video shows moment Alec Baldwin killed Halyna Hutchins on setMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: keir starmer hints labour could
story: Exclusive: Keir Starmer hints Labour could stand election candidate against Jeremy CorbynEx-Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has sat as an independent MP since being suspended by the party in October Labour leader Keir Starmer on the campaign trail Image: Rowan Grfiths   Daily MirrorByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Feb |comments Labour could stand a candidate against former party leader Jeremy Corbyn, Keir Starmer has signalled. The Labour leader said he was on a mission to prevent Labour being linked to anti-Semitism for good - and did not rule out putting forward a candidate in Mr Corbynaposs seat at the next election. Mr Corbyn was suspended from Labour in October  over his reaction to a damning report on handling of allegations of anti-Jewish hate within the partyaposs ranks.He has represented Islington North since  but he would have to stand as an independent candidatehe fails to regain the whip by the next election. Mr Starmer was pressed on his predecessoraposs future by the Mirror as he hit the campaign trail ahead of next monthaposs Birmingham Erdington by-election.  Asked how he planned to ensure Labour upheld the values he hoped to roll out across the country, Mr Starmer said: “I said I would tear anti-Semitism out of the party by the roots in my acceptance speech. “We have been doing that and we have made progress on it.”Pressed on whether that would include standing a Labour candidate in Mr Corbyn’s seat, Mr Starmer said: “Well, Jeremy Corbyn doesn’t have a Labour whip at the moment.“That’s the position he finds himself in, and it’s down to the response he made to the report on anti-Semitism.” It follows claims Mr Corbyn could be deselected by the party in his safe seat of Islington North, which he has held since .It is understood he plans to stand at the next general election, whether it is for Labour or as an independent candidate. Mr Starmer also promised he is taking allegations of Islamophobia as seriously as anti-Semitism. “There is absolutely no hierarchy here, he said. “We have to root out Islamophobia in just the same way as weaposd have to root out anti-Semitism. “And we do it with the same determination and energy. And Iaposm absolutely as prepared to take tough decisions on Islamophobia as I am on anti-Semitism.” Askedhe had spoken to Labour MPs concerned by the issue, he said he “talked to all of our MPs pretty well all the time but admitted it was harder to keep in touch during Covid. He added: “Iaposve got good relations with all of our MPs, I donapost think thereaposs any MP that wouldnapost be able to tell me what they think.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Labour PartyJeremy CorbynPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: labour election hopeful vows stand
story: Exclusive: Labour by-election hopeful vows to stand up for poor in honour of late fatherPaulette Hamilton broke down in tears as she described how much she wished her dad could see her elected in next months Birmingham Erdington by-electionLabour leader Keir Starmer on the campaign trail with Labour candidate Paulette Hamilton Image: Rowan Grfiths   Daily MirrorByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Feb |commentsLabouraposs by-election candidate Paulette Hamilton has pledged to use her experience of discrimination and poverty to stand up for struggling communities in Parliament.The former nurse is battling to win next monthaposs Birmingham Erdington by-election, with voters heading to the polls following the death of Labour MP Jack Dromey.Ms Hamilton broke down in tears as she described how much she wished her father could have seen her elected to Parliament - after he died only two weeks ago. I wanted him to see me go to Parliament, she told the Mirror. Imagine a poor family from the inner cities and watch their daughter go to Parliament - you donapost know what that means. “He worked so hard for me and my family. I just wanted to stand up and say, ‘This is for you’.  Ms Hamilton, , grew up in a tight-knit family without much money. We had a party when we got our first washing machine,” she recalled. It was magical.” She said not going to private school or possessing family wealth had been a driving factor of her career, from nursing through to politics. Ms Hamilton said she knew she might face challenges in politics as a black woman. Iaposve faced racism and faced issues where people have thought perhaps I wasnapost good enough to do it because of the areas Iaposve grown up in, she said. I remember once a senior telling meyou are going to achieve anything in nursing, you donapost just have to be as good as your white counterpart, you have to be twice as good. She takes the role of serving the community seriously, especially as Jack Dromey was well known in the constituency for speaking up for everyone. Iaposll never be Jack Dromey. Iaposm Paulette Hamilton.  And I know this community deserves people like Jack who are passionate and want to fight for the issues that they feel that they want challenged in government.Askedshe would be nervous to grill Boris Johnson, she shot back: No.She admitted to being unprepared for the prospect of receiving death threats and abuse as she is a black woman. Ms Hamilton said: Iaposm not gonna tell you Iaposm prepared. But what Iaposve seen over the last month or so, from the MPs that have come to Birmingham, is that they seem very supportive. And so all I can do is learn from people that have gone there before me. Just try not to make the same mistakes. AndI get it wrong, just work with the powers that be to look at the issues. As well as her strong work ethic, Ms Hamilton has beaming smile on her face that lingers through the interview and when speaking to locals. Asked what her secret is to looking happy, Ms Hamilton replied: Iaposve got a good husband who loves me, and has for  years. Iaposve got five lovely children who absolutely root for me, a really good extended family and a great network of friends. Chuckling, she added: And also Iaposm a beautul girl walking about! Sharing her plans for Erdington, Ms Hamilton said: I want to see our high street as something we can be proud of, a town where people have high earnings. We have to help people feel proud of their community. Voters will head to the polls in Birmingham Erdington on March  to elect their new MP. The West Midlands seat has been Labour since it was created in . title: matt hancock broke law over
story: Matt Hancock broke law over Tory peer Dido Hardings appointment during pandemicThe High Court found former Health Secretary Matt Hancock failed to comply with equalities duties when he appointed Baroness Harding and ex-Sainsburys boss Mike Coupe to top jobsFormer Health Secretary Matt Hancock Image: Crown ByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political EditorBrian Farmer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Ex-Health Secretary Matt Hancock broke equality law by handing Tory peer Dido Harding a top health job, the High Court has found.Two judges ruled that Mr Hancock did not comply with a public sector equality duty in relation to appointments of Conservative peer Baroness Dido Harding and Mike Coupe to posts in . Race equality thinktank the Runnymede Trust was granted the declaration by Lord Justice Singh and Mr Justice Swt after a High Court hearing in December. The Good Law Project joined the Runnymede Trust in the action. The judges ruled that the Runnymede Trust had sufficient standing to bring a public sector equality duty challenge but GLP did not.The ruling centred on Mr Hancockaposs decision to appoint Baroness Harding as interim executive chair of the National Institute for Health Protection in August  and ex-Sainsburyaposs boss Mr Coupe as director of testing for NHS Test and Trace in September . Lawyers representing the two organisations suggested that people outside the tight circle in which senior Conservative politicians and their friends moved were not being given opportunities. They said an unfair policy was being challenged. Ministers disputed the claims made against them. Jason Coppel QC, who led the two organisationsapos legal teams, told Lord Justice Singh and Mr Justice Swt that the challenge was based on equality legislation and public law. He said the Government had a policy or practice of making appointments to posts critical to the pandemic response without adopting any, or any sufficient, fair or open competitive processes. Mr Coppel said people less likely to be known or connected to decision-makers were put at a disadvantage. He also said the Government was failing to offer remuneration for high-level full-time roles and excluding all candidates who were not already wealthy or held other posts for which they would continue to be paid.  Lord Justice Singh and Mr Justice Swt said in a written ruling: It is the process leading up to the two decisions which has been found by this court to be in breach of the public sector equality duty. For those reasons we will grant a declaration to the Runnymede Trust that the Secretary of State for Health and Social Care did not comply with the public sector equality duty in relation to the decisions how to appoint Baroness Harding as interim executive chair of the NIHP in August  and Mr Coupe as director of testing for NHSTT in September . Dr Halima Begum, Chief Executive of the Runnymede Trust, welcomed the findings. She said: “The judgement handed down today by the High Court is incredibly signicant to the British people. It shows the importance of the Public Sector Equality Duty and its role in protecting the people of this nation from the closed shop of Government appointments, not least in a time of national crisis where people from our minority communities were dying from Covid in hugely disproportionate numbers. Mr Hancock’s spokesman said the judgement aposthe claim brought by Good Law Project fails in its entiretyapos, therefore highlighting the fact this group continues to waste the courtaposs time. He said the High Court ruling “states that aposthe evidence provides no support ... at allapos for the allegation that Dido Harding secured senior positions on the basis of apospersonal or political connectionsapos in the Government”. He said: They accept these aposwere urgent recruitment processes which needed to find highly specialised, experienced and available candidates within a short space of time. Letaposs not forget, we were dealing with an unprecedented global pandemic where time was of the essence in order to protect and save lives. Mr Hancock resigned as Health Secretary last year after admitting to breaching his own Covid guidelines by kissing an aide in his office. news politics new-covid-rule-changes-announced-"Vaughan Gething ‘fairly surprised’ at Johnson’s Covid announcementByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsAnother  people died after catching Covid in the UK yesterday.But after two years, Boris Johnson has decided the nation has had all the virus restrictions it can tolerate.On Monday  February, the Prime Minister will announce a long-term plan to ‘live with Covid’ in England.He is expected to scrap all self-isolation, even for people who have the virus, from around Thursday  February. He is also likely to confirm the date free lateral flow and PCR tests will be axed - though it’s not thought this will actually happen next week. The £ self-isolation payment for low-income workers and legal powers for councils both face being scrapped. Scroll down for the full guide to the changes - or join the debate in the comments Unions also fear the ability to claim Statutory Sick Pay from Day One of Covid isolation will be axed when current laws expire. And charities worry immunocompromised Brits will be thrown to the wolves with little support.Meanwhile Boris Johnson’s plan could kick vaccines for all children over five into operation, though the announcement of this looks set to be brought forward after Wales and Scotland both unveiled their plans in the last  hours.For holidaymakers, Passenger Locator Forms could be simplied further, or even scrapped completelyTransport Secretary Grant Shapps gets his way.Travel testing, however, is likely to stay for unvaccinated people entering the UK for the foreseeable future. Here’s everything we know about what is likely to be announced.Self-isolation laws scrappedLegal Covid self-isolation is due to be scrapped - evenyou currently have the virus - from as soon as Thursday  February. The decision will end almost exactly two years of legally-enforced isolation for people who test positive. But it raises ethical dilemmas about whether to go to work and put others at risk, especiallyyou can no longer claim a £ isolation paymentor sick pay. Despite scrapping legal isolation, No said: “We’re not saying isolation is pointless. We’d expect anyone with an infectious disease to take steps not to spread that disease further - a colleague at work with flu, for example. Currently people who test positive must go into self-isolation for at least five full days in England, a period that has been repeatedly cut from  days and seven days. Fears Statutory Sick Pay will be stripped back Unions and Labour fear the right to claim Statutory Sick Payfrom Day One of Covid isolation will be axed.The £.-a-week payment is usually only available from the fourth day of illness, after three ‘waiting days’ are complete. This was cut to the first day for Covid cases.But the power is contained within the Coronavirus Act , which could lapse in its entirety by the end of March. It is thought ministers may need to pass new laws to continue the ‘Day One’ SSP power, and they have not yet said whether they plan to do that. Sources suggested the issue was still being worked out. TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady - who has long called for SSP to be increased and extended to more part-time workers - said: “It’s vital that sick pay remains a day one right and is made available to all. “Workers who are laid low by Covid must be able to make ends meet – not pushed into financial hardship.”A date for scrapping free lateral flow testsBoris Johnson’s plan is expected to set a timetable for the end of free lateral flow tests, with people having to pay instead.The government warned last summer it would eventually stop paying for these rapid tests due to the huge cost of the NHS.Sources told the Mirror that claims the tests themselves will end next week are wide of the mark. However, the Living with Covid plan could set a date in the future for when they are cut off. It’s not known how much lateral flow tests will cost, but estimates have put it at £ for a pack of seven. A date for scrapping free PCR tests and Test and TraceIt’s thought next week’s plan may contain a date for ending free ‘gold standard’ PCR tests as England’s Covid infrastructure is wound down. Whitehall sources told thethe Treasury is trying to cut the £bn-a-year cost, which will mean having to phase out free testing and all but ending the contact-tracing system. Scientists have raised the alarm about ending these free tests with reports suggesting they could cost £ each privately. According to reports, only health and social care workers and .million vulnerable people will continue to get free PCRs. Prof Lawrence Young of Warwick University said: “Living with Covid doesn’t mean letting our guard down”. Covid travel Passenger Locator Form could be simplied or axedFully-vaccinated people entering the UK do not need to take any Covid tests, under changes that happened on February . But they still need to fill in a Passenger Locator Form - albeit a ‘simplied’ one - and further changes to this are possible in next week’s Covid plan. It’s understood the Department for Transport is pressing to further simply the Passenger Locator Form - or get rid of it completely. However, it is thought there is only a slim chance of the form being axed altogether, with health officials still worried about needing to track new iants coming in to the UK. Meanwhile, unvaccinated people still need to take one pre-departure test and one post-arrival test before entering the UK. It’s understood this rule will stay for the foreseeable future and no changes to it are due next week. £ self-isolation payment could be scrappedThe £ self-isolation payment for poor workers with Covid could end as the legal requirement to quarantine is scrapped. The Test and Trace Support Payment was introduced in September  to help low-wage workers afford to self-isolate for up to  days. No final decisions have been announced yet over the future of the £ payment, and its status is being considered by the government this week. An announcement is due on Monday.  Legal powers for councils will goThe legal change will also end remaining powers which authorities had under the  Coronavirus Act in England to close some venues. However, these powers were barely ever used, because powers for lockdowns flow from a separate law passed in . And the vast majority of Coronavirus Act powers - including on detention, events, gatherings, shops and restaurants and schools - already expired in September . Only a few of the more draconian powers - including the power to suspend port operations - remained in the Act. Vaccines for all children over fiveAll children over five will be able to get vaccinated against Covid- from April. The “non-urgent offer” to the parents of nearly six million - year olds was confirmed by the Government moments after advice issued by the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation . Two smaller doses of the Pfizer jab,  weeks apart, will be available to this age group to help control future Covid waves after Covid curbs have been lted. It is understood there are no plans for a major publicity drive to encourage this age group to be vaccinated and it will be left very much up to parents to decide. Itaposs understood a rollout for over-s will be less urgent than previous vaccine drives, due to the very low risk Covid poses to younger kids. The idea is that ordinary NHS care shouldn’t be interrupted to give kids the jab, like it was for adults. All children over  have been able to get the Pfizer Covid jab since September last year. Currently, only the most vulnerable kids aged  to  are eligible. They are offered two jabs but at a lower dose than for adults -  micrograms instead of . news politics russia-sends--more-troops-"Ukraine crisis: Armed Forces Minster gives harsh reality checkByDan BloomOnline Political EditorTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsThe UK and US have accused Russia of boosting its forces on the Ukrainian border by as many as , troops - despite claims it was withdrawing some soldiers. A US senior administration official last night blasted Russiaaposs claim it was withdrawing troops from the border with Ukraine. They received a lot of attention for that claim, both here and around the world. But we now know it was , the official said. The anonymous official said Russia has increased its troop presence along the Ukrainian border by as many as , troops, with many of them arriving as recently as Wednesday. No details or evidence were given of how the US knew this to be the case. But the , figure was today backed by UK Armed Forces minister James Heappey. He said Britain has not necessarily been able to very the , figure, but warned imagery overnight showed a new bridge and a large field hospital and he was very worried. “Troop movements towards the border continue”, Mr Heappey told the BBC. For all the talk about de-escalation in Moscow, I’m afraid what we’re seeing in the opposite and we’re very worried about it.  He added: “All of the conditions are set, and from the moment President Putin takes a decision, it is literally just a matter of minutes before military effect could be felt in Ukrainian cities. “That’s dferent however to inevitability. I have a gut feeling because I’m seeing what I’m seeing, and I don’t think you spend that amount of money in putting that number of troops and planes and ships into an area unless you mean it.But I have hope that a diplomatic process can succeed, because the consequences of that not being the case are that tens of thousands of people could die.” The UKaposs Lieutenant General Sir Jim Hockenhull, the Chief of Defence Intelligence, added: Contrary to their claims, Russia continues to build up military capabilities near Ukraine. This includes sightings of additional armoured vehicles, helicopters and a field hospital moving towards Ukraineaposs borders. Russia has the military mass in place to conduct an invasion of Ukraine. UK Foreign Secretary Liz Truss warned Moscow could drag out the crisis for months in an attempt to undermine Western unity.  Moscow denies it has any plans to invade, and Russiaaposs defence ministry said yesterday its forces were pulling back after exercises near Ukraine. It published video that it said showed forces leaving the Crimean peninsula. But Ms Truss said it was essential the UK and its allies not be lulled into a  sense of security, adding: In fact the Russian military build-up shows no signs of slowing. We must have no illusions that Russia could drag this out much longer in a brazen ploy to spend weeks more -not months - subverting Ukraine and challenging Western unity. This is a test of our mettle. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said in an interview on MSNBC on Wednesday that critical units were moving towards the border. On Tuesday, US President Joe Biden said the United States estimated that , Russian troops had encircled Ukraine, an increase from previous estimates of about ,. Russia had said that its forces - part of a huge buildup that has been accompanied by demands to the West for sweeping security guarantees - were pulling back after taking part in exercises in southern and western military districts near Ukraine.  But NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg said moving troops and tanks back and forth did not amount to proof of a pullout. Liz Truss will reaffirm support for Ukrainian sovereignty on a trip to Kyiv this week as part of efforts to deter a possible Russian invasion, urging Moscow to end its military buildup along the border. Truss will hold talks with Ukraineaposs Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba and will then deliver a speech in Kyiv where she will warn Russia it faces economic pain and global isolationit invades its former Soviet neighbour. In a speech in Kyiv, the Foreign Secretary will say the path of diplomacy remains openMoscow really does want a peaceful resolute to the crisis . We are ready to talk. But we are very clear -they decide to continue down the path of aggression, there will be massive consequences bringing Russia severe economic costs and pariah status, she will say. Following her visits to Ukraine and Poland, Ms Truss will travel on to attend the Munich Security Conference with other Nato foreign and defence ministers.  Russiaaposs deputy ambassador to the United Nations Dmitry Polyanskiy again dismissed the claims as fantasies by Western politicians. This is a very ridiculous situation, there has been hysteria, even hype, fanned for several weeks by our Western colleagues, he told ITVaposs Peston programme. They convinced each other and the whole world that Russia was about to invade, they were even naming concrete dates. So it happened in their minds, in their heads. Britain has already said it is doubling the number of troops in Estonia, with around  members of The Royal Welsh battlegroup heading from Sennelager in Germany and bases in Europe for the Baltic state, while  Royal Marine commandos are being despatched to Poland.  Four additional RAF Typhoon jets are heading to Cyprus to join Nato patrols over eastern Europe while offshore patrol vessel HMS Trent will shortly be joined in the eastern Mediterranean by HMS Diamond, a Type  destroyer. Meanwhile, so-called golden visas for wealthy foreign investors are expected to be scrapped by the Government amid concerns over links between Russia and the UK. Those eligible for the tier one investor visa, launched in , must have at least £ million in investment funds and have a UK bank account. It has been under review due to repeated concerns that the system could be exploited because not enough background checks are made on applicants. And the BBC now reports an unnamed Government source has confirmed the scheme will be abandoned in an announcement to be made next week. title: tories ban teachers promoting black
story: Tories ban teachers from promoting Black Lives Matter in political bias crackdownNew guidance says Britains imperial past must be taught in a balanced manner and teachers should not promote partisan political viewsDemonstrators wearing protective face masks and face coverings hold placards during a Black Lives Matter protest in Parliament Square Image: REUTERSByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsTeachers are being ordered to avoid promoting groups like Black Lives Matter in a new crackdown on political content in the classroom. New guidance published today says schools should avoid advocating for organisations with contested aims or views when teaching pupils about racism. Britainaposs imperial past must be taught in a balanced manner and teachers should avoid controversial theories about historical figures, it states. Children must be taught that racism has no place in society but campaigners such as Black Lives Matter could be considered partisan political views. The guidance tells schools to offer pupils a balanced account of opposing views and not to advocate for ideas such as withdrawing funding from the police.  It says: Partisan political views must not be promoted to pupils, including by encouraging pupils to support campaign groups advocating such views. Teachers discussing the decriminalisation of homosexuality are told not to present discriminatory beliefs held at the time in an uncritical way - and make it clear they are not acceptable today. Schools already have a legal duty to ensure political impartiality in the classroom and teachers are required to promote values like democracy and the rule of law. Teachers are banned from encouraging pupils to back a political party or candidate in an election. But schools are allowed to teach children about dferent political parties and views - as long as they donapost promote a particular ideas.The latest guidance comes after Mr Zahawi waded into a row over a primary school in Nottingham where pupils had written letters to their Labour MP Lilian Greenwood about the Partygate scandal. Labour accused the Education Secretary of playing to his own party with the new guidance, while union bosses warned it could limit teachers efforts to discuss serious subjects.Shadow Schools Minister Stephen Morgan said: This hopelessly thin guidance shows Nadhim Zahawi is more focused on playing to Tory backbenchers than on the real challenges facing our schools.Dr Mary Bousted, Joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, said: There is absolutely no need for new guidance on how to appropriately handle political and social subjects in schools. Very good guidance already exists and this is followed up and down the country. It has always been the case that educators take their responsibilities for teaching in these areas seriously and carry it out with considerable thought. “We note Nadhim Zahawi’s intention that he ‘does not seek to limit the range of political issues that schools can and do teach about’. But in practice his guidance will have the opposite effect.Geoff Barton, General Secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said young people were exposed to a swirl of misinformation online and schools needed to provide a safe space for discussions.  He said: The vast majority of teachers are very good at managing these discussions in a way that is balanced and impartial. We welcome anything which helps them to navigate this dficult territory. However, we are keen that this should not be over-prescriptive as it could have the unintended consequence of deterring open discussions.” Launching the new guidance, Mr Zahawi said: I know one of the reasons many teachers feel so passionate about the profession is the remarkable role they play in young people’s lives, helping them understand more about themselves and their views of the world. I don’t want there to be any barriers – real or perceived – to teachers’ vital work in this space, which is why I am reinforcing that no subject is off-limits in the classroom, as long as it is treated in an age-appropriate way, with sensitivity and respect, and without promoting contested theories as fact. title: andrews money coming from how
story: Where is Andrews money coming from  How Queen bailout could end up costing taxpayerPrince Andrew receives £, from the Queen every year and also has an annual £, naval pension. Norman Baker says Andrew has, over the years, pulled in money from shady sourcesPrince Andrew attends the annual Founders Day Parade at the Royal Hospital Cha in  Image: Getty ImagesByNorman Baker:,  Feb So Prince Andrew has finally paid off Virginia Giuffre, at a cost rumoured to be £million. That’s a lot of money to give to someone he says he has no recollection of meeting. So where’s all the money coming from  Well it’s not from his handouts from the Queen, who gives him £, a year. Nor is it from his annual £, naval pension. Andrew has, over the years, pulled in money from shady sources. His marital home, Sunninghill Park, sat unloved on the market, empty for years before being sold to the dodgy billionaire son-in-law of the Kazakhstan dictator for £m. Why would he pay £m over the odds and then demolish the house without even living in it   Another dodgy deal gave him a % commission for sending a couple of emails relating to a £.m Kazakh infrastructure scheme, though that one fell through when Kazakh soldiers killed a group of striking oil workers. But now he is clearly short of cash. He has had to rely on the tycoon David Rowland to pay off a £.m loan from Banque Havilland. No doubt the fact Andrew had hosted his son Jonathan at Buckingham Palace when he was trying to land a lucrative deal involving the Royal Estate did no harm. It seems clear that the Queen is going to have to bail him out. Most of us stop cadging off our parents when we are in our s, but not, it appears, the -year-old Duke of York. The Queen, of course, is fabulously wealthy. But noises from the Palace suggest she could fund Andrew via the Duchy of Lancaster, a sort of royal slush fund. The Queen already pays out her annual support to the Royal Family from this source and offsets these payments against tax. If she bails out Andrew this way, that will in effect reduce her tax bill and mean the public purse is part-subsidising Andrew’s shenanigans. That is outrageous. We need a clear statement from the Palace that no public money will be used for a payoff. It is also high time the Public Accounts Committee looked into the whole murky business of royal finances.
