title: brexit eu rules changes imports
story: Are you ready to import from the EU into the UK  Pasta firm has genius idea to helpAny business importing from the European Union into the UK must now be able to prove their meet the new rules of origin requirementsAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Feb Rules of origin are an important trading requirement. If you sell goods to the EU, or buy goods from the EU and bring them into the UK, you need to be able to prove that they meet the new rules of origin requirements to access preferential tarfs. It’s vital you understand the new rules to keep your business moving. To benefit from the preferential tarfs, you must have proof that any goods you import from the EU originate there, or any goods you export to the EU originate in the UK. Proof of origin can either be a statement of origin completed by the exporter, or evidence of the importer’s knowledge of where products originate. If you cannot prove the origin, you or your EU customer may be liable to pay the full rate of customs duty and could face penalties. Andrew Macleod, founder of London-based restaurant brand Emilia’s Crafted Pasta, explains that imports from the EU are vital to his brand: “We import ingredients directly from Italy, including special cured meats, cheeses, drinks and alcohol. Each of our suppliers is hand-picked.”  Has he had to make any changes to his business now that there are new import rules in place  “Yes – of course we already knew the origin of all the goods we import as we source everything carefully. But we’ve trained two of our managers on the rules around importing, so we know that we have staff in house who are well versed in the process.”  And having successfully navigated the changes, what advice would Andrew offer other businesses that import  “We found using a customs agent really helps the process run smoothly, but it’s equally important that you understand the rules yourself,” he says. “It’s not too late, and the gov.uk site has lots of valuable information.”  You must be able to prove the origin of any product you import You can choose to work with a freight forwarder or courier To benefit from preferential tarfs, you must be able to prove that any goods you import originated in the EU Note:you’re moving goods between Great Britain and Northern Ireland, rules of origin work dferently. Contact the Trader Support Service for up-to-date guidance and support. FIND OUT WHAT YOU NEED TO DO. Visit gov.uk rules-of-origin

title: britain become republic prince andrew
story: Britain will become a republicPrince Andrew s to public leKevin Maguire writes that Prince Andrews banishment from public le should be permanent after paying his sex abuse accuser a substantial sum to settle sordid charges he deniedQueen Elizabeth II and Prince Andrew on the balcony of Buckingham Palace during Trooping The Colour in  Image: Getty ImagesopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Feb If the royals permit the Duke of Shame to slime his way back on to the balcony there’ll be a revolution which turns Britain into a republic. Forever tainted Andrew’s banishment from public le must be permanent after paying his sex abuse accuser a substantial sum to settle sordid charges he denied. Because the court of public opinion will reach its own verdict on the U-turning prince now commending the bravery of a victim, Virginia Giuffre, his team disgracefully accused of lying in a stomach-churning smear campaign. And hoisting the white flag over Buckingham Palace to avoid a court inquisition means a man who until yesterday considered it honourable to be the guest of a convicted paedophile can never openly clear his name.  The donation to Giuffre’s charity combined with avow to campaign against sex trafficking and that apology indicate who won. She did. He still lost. The question remains unanswered about what to do with befouled Uncle Andrew despite relief in royal circles an Emily Maitlis mauling with knobs on is averted in a New York courtroom. Sneak him into platinum jubilee celebrations and the Queen will besmirch  years to rehabilitate a favourite son who’d be safer for the family locked in the Tower. Stripping him of a few courtesy titles and recognising the armed forces want nothing to do with Andrew isn’t enough.  The riot act must be read to him and a public declaration there is no way back nailed to the gates of Windsor Castle. Andrew remaining ninth in line to the throne and continuing to enjoy the perks of royalty is an insult to all women. It also goes to the heart of the rottenness of a hereditary monarchy, permanently elevating one family over millions of better others. Let her be Elizabeth the Last and vive la British democratic revolution. title: childrens home shut down after
story: Childrens home shut down after boy went four months without a bath or change of clothesThe home in Bolton was blasted as inadequate by Ofsted, with the watchdog listing a series of serious failings that left children at riskThe staff team is very inexperienced to care for two very complex children, the report saidImage: Getty ImagesBySeamus McDonnellThomas Molloy:,  Feb A young boy went for four months without taking a bath, having a home-cooked meal or changing his clothes at a home for vulnerable children, inspectors say.The home in Bolton was blasted as aposinadequateapos by Ofsted, with the watchdog listing a series of serious failings that left children at risk. A councillor described the report as deeply shocking and upsetting, the Manchester Evening News reports. On one occasion, inspectors say a child was put in harmaposs way by staff aposcarrying out cardiac pulmonary resuscitation on them when this was not necessaryapos. And, in a separate incident, staff at the home did not enter a childaposs bedroom for four months aposdespite there being evidence of flies and a pungent smell coming from the room and spreading throughout the homeapos.  The home, which we are not naming in order to ensure the anonymity of the children, has had its registration with Ofsted revoked, according to the report. Staff are not effective in supporting children’s health and well-being, it read. A spokesperson for Achieve, the firm which operates the childrenaposs home, said staff would work with Bolton council to investigate the incidents in Oftedaposs report. In the inspection report, which covers visits on January  and  this year, Ofsted inspectors Chris Scully and Michelle Edge wrote: The registered manager and staff have failed to meet the basic care needs of children. One child has been signicantly neglected and he has not bathed, changed his clothes or been provided with a home-cooked meal since he moved into the home in September . Adding: Staff are not effective in supporting children’s health and well-being. The registered manager and staff fail to take action when children refuse to take their medication.Another issue listed in the report involved a child who refused to leave the home during fire drills for over three months.Despite knowing this, staff failed to put systems in place to help the child in an emergency. The report added: Currently, only two members of staff hold a childcare qualication one of these is the registered manager. The staff team is very inexperienced to care for two very complex children. Staff have not been supported by the manager to safely care for these children. In response to the damning findings, Bolton councillor Adele Warren said the childrenaposs home in question was an example of a wider problem. The report is deeply shocking and upsetting. Children who have been through so much already shouldn’t have to go through that as well in a location which is supposed to be safe and secure, she explained. I appealed it at the planning committee and it was declined but unfortunately they then applied for a certicate of lawful development, which there’s no recourse to object to. I did write to Ofsted and asked them not to grant registration but unfortunately they did.  It’s a dficult subject because these are extremely vulnerable children and you have to try and find a balance between trying to do the right thing for everybody but in Bolton we have so many private children’s homes and only  percent of the children placed there are local children. This puts a massive pressure on the availability of homes for our own children and I believe it’s a national scandal what’s happening in the private care home sector and I think a lot of people are just in it to make money. Some children’s placements are £, per week so some organisations are making a hell of a lot of money on the back of vulnerable children. These children deserve the best and to not even have adults that are adequately trained to look after them, it’s just not good enough. A spokesperson for Achieve said: We have voluntarily revoked our registration after the incident that occurred in our care home and we are working with the Local Authority to investigate it further. A Bolton council spokesperson said the home had undergone aposdue diligence and all the appropriate checksapos to be registered with Ofsted initially and that regular independent visits took place.  They added: “Bolton Council are working with Ofsted, health partners, and the provider to review the service that was provided at the home and consider what could have been done dferently to inform practice. “Children placed in the home were removed as soon as concerns were raised, and alternative placements were sourced within  hours. “This case demonstrates a broader national issue of sufficiency, quality and capacity within the care system, especially as children with complex needs are discharged from hospital settings at short notice due to a reduced number of hospital beds. “Like other local authorities, we are working with national partners, and the Independent Review of Children’s Social Care, to address this problem and ensure there is a more robust approach to registering providers. “There is also a need to enhance the monitoring of the quality of placements for children on a regular basis.” Read MoreRead More Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON HospitalsCare homesNursing homesChildcare" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news five-times-royals-put-foot-"Prince Andrew: What’s next for Duke after Giuffre settlement ByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Feb  The civil sex abuse case against Prince Andrew has been brought to a close after he agreed to a settlement with his accuser. And sources say it was the Queen and Prince Charles who p ut substantial pressure on the Duke of York to come to an out of court deal - said to be worth £million.The Firm is said to have wanted a settlement agreed so the case did not overshadow the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee year. Well placed royal sources said Andrew was under “intense pressure from the very top” to ensure a deal was done after a US judge last month rejected the duke’s bid to have the case dismissed. And itaposs not the first time royals including the Queen, Charles and Andrewaposs other siblings have put their foot down amid his legal troubles... Stepping back from public le  Itaposs long been thought that Andrew is Her Majesty favourite son, and sheaposs said to have had a far more hands-on relationship with when he was a child than his older brother Prince Charles. Royal expert Penny Junor once said: I think the Queen has always had a bit of a blind spot when it comes to Prince Andrew.But after giving a car crash interview on BBC Newsnight about his association with Jeffy Epstein, Andrewaposs royal role diminished as his mother approved him stepping back from public le and reportedly cancelled a milestone birthday party. In the days after the Newsnight interview was broadcast in , Andrew sensationally quit public le for the foreseeable future in a statement - approved by the Queen.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. He said at the time: It has become clear to me over the last few days that the circumstances relating to my former association with Jeffrey Epstein has become a major disruption to my family’s work and the valuable work going on in the many organisations and charities that I am proud to support. Therefore, I have asked Her MajestyI may step back from public duties for the foreseeable future, and she has given her permission. Birthday party axed Andrew celebrated his landmark th birthday on February , .But it was reported that the Queen cancelled a birthday bash she had planned for him and downgraded it to a small family dinner. The Queen hosted a lavish reception at Buckingham Palace to mark the Prince of Wales’ th birthday in November .But in the wake of allegations against him at the time, a similar party for Andrew didnapost happen. No way back In October, it was reported that Prince Charles, Princess Anne and Prince Edward ruled out ato public le for Andrew during a get-together.According to the Sunday Times, a meeting was held in January , where Andrewaposs siblings were in agreement that their brother should never be allowed toto public le, an insider claimed. A source said at the time: “Nine months ago Charles, Anne and Edward had a meeting, a summit, and agreed there was no way back for him.” Titles stripped Last month, Andrew suffered another blow when he learned he was being stripped of his honorary military titles and royal patronages. He was said to be utterly devastated by his mother’s bombshell decision, which came after the Sunday People exclusively revealed Her Majesty would reluctantly strip her son of his prized roleshe did not resign. A Buckingham Palace spokesperson said: With The Queen’s approval and agreement, The Duke of York’s military affiliations and Royal patronages have been ed to The Queen. The Duke of York will continue not to undertake any public duties and is defending this case as a private citizen. A royal source said: All of The Duke’s roles have been handed back to The Queen with immediate effect for redistribution to other Members of the Royal Family - will notto The Duke of York. The Duke of York will no longer use the style ‘His Royal Highness’ in any official capacity. Balcony appearance  However, itaposs not just since his legal battle that Andrew has seen other royals put their foot down when it came to him. In , the Queen was celebrating her Diamond Jubilee of  years on the throne - and an appearance by the royals on the Buckingham Palace balcony was planned.It was reported that Charles had a hand in the decision for only senior royals, such as the Duchess of Cornwall, Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge, to appear on the balcony - leaving Andrew dismayed.  Royal expert Richard Kay wrote in the Daily Mail in : For Andrew, according to one close figure, being excluded from the balcony scene was a sudden and totally unexpected demotion from front-rank to peripheral royal. It was ‘like a dagger to his heart and he hasn’t got over it’.But this was a dramatic statement of intent by Charles, who long ago decided that when he is king the Royal Family would be ‘slimmed down’. But as a friend of the Duke of York says: ‘The speed and suddenness with which Charles has acted has taken Andrew’s breath away. It’s dreadfully high-handed.’ Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror. title: it embarrassing royal family face
story: It is embarrassing for Royal Family to face scandals on Queens Platinum Jubilee yearThe reputation of the Royal Family has been tarnished by Prince Andrew’s court case. The Met Police also opened an investigation into claims Prince Charles’s charity offered honours to wealthy donorsThe Queen is celebrating her Platinum Jubilee this year Image: Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Feb This should have been a year of undimmed celebration for the Queen as the country marks her Platinum Jubilee. While the nation’s affection for Her Majesty remains undiminished, the reputation of the Royal Family has been tarnished by Prince Andrew’s unsavoury court case. To add to the Queen’s woes, the politan Police has opened an investigation into claims Prince Charles’s charity offered honours to wealthy donors. Clarence House insists Charles did not know what was happening at his foundation and is not involved in its day-to-day running. But the revelation is another blight on what should be a momentous year for the House of Windsor. For the Royal Family to be hit by one scandal is unfortunate but to be rocked by two in as many days is deeply embarrassing. The Queen described the year of  which saw the separation of Charles and Diana, the orce of Princess Anne and the fire at Windsor Castle as her annus horribilis. It would be deeply unfair on her Majestythe year in which she marks  years on the throne turns out to be equally grim.  Paying the price Soaring inflation is another blow to households hit by sky-high fuel bills. Prices are now outstripping wages and the recent increases in pensions and benefits. Rishi Sunak claims he understands the pressures on family finances. But he is still pressing ahead with a National Insurance rise this April. If the Chancellor genuinely cares about the cost of living crisis he would rethink this tax hike and help people more with heating bills. He should also send a clear signal to bosses that workers deserve a rise. Working people should not have to pay the price for this Government’s economic mismanagement.  Double trouble Forecasters warn that Storm Eunice could be the worst one in decades. Coming hot on the heels of Storm Dudley, there really is no calm before the storm. news uk-news major-change-covid-testing-coming-"Covid-: Dr Amir surprised at how soon isolation will endByBenjamin LynchTrends Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA signicant rule change in the coming weeks could impact on the pocket of Brits as they learn to deal with the coronavirus becoming endemic. The government hopes to announce that an end to all Covid restrictions, including the mandatory period required for self-isolating, will be in place by the end of February.Parliament is currently on recess, but the Prime Minister is due to announce his plan for living with Covid when MPsnext week on Monday, February . Another change, this time to testing, is also likely to be announced. Boris Johnson looks set to unveil the change that could impact Brits up to £ at a time, as the UK looks to learn to live with the virus.So what is the change and why will Brits be charged   Will PCR tests be scrapped  Free PCR tests now look set to be scrapped and could cost people £they want to get their hands on one. The Living Safely With Covid plan is due to be published on February  and may well include the plans to scrap free PCRs.  PCR tests have been vital to determinea person has Covid, as they are more accurate than lateral flow testsand have become a requirement for travel to and from certain countries around the world at ious points during the pandemic. The hope is that LFTs becoming more widely available will mean PCRs will not be so heavily relied upon. Why are free PCR tests set to be scrapped   The Treasury will be hoping to save billions by announcing the end to free tests. Covid figures have taken a downward trend recently. The seven-day average has been falling since January .  However, UK Health and Security Agencywants the government to keep providing free tests until at least the start of April and some experts are also concerned that the changes will be taken as a signal by people with Covid that they should continue to mix in public setting, despite having clear symptoms of the virus. title: man finds out needs transplant
story: Man finds out he needs transplant after borrowing friends Fitbit to check heart rateRyan Gabb borrowed a friends Fitbit and discovered his heart was racing at over  beats per minute. He had to give up his job in a factory and has been on the transplant list for four yearsRyan Gabbdiscovered he needed a new heart after borrowing a friends FitbitByStephen WhiteNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments Ryan Gabb borrowed a friend’s Fitbit....and the fitness monitor told him he needed a new heart.The -year-old discovered his heart was racing at over  beats per minute. His GP sent him straight to hospital where he was told he had Dilated Cardiomyopathyand he would likely need a heart transplant. Ryan explained: “I had been feeling unwell for a few weeks, just general tiredness and flu-type symptoms that I couldn’t shake off. “It was getting worse and I was starting to become breathless too.”Ryan, of Wrexham, North Wales, who has been on the transplant list for four years, had to give up his job in a factory. Now fitted with a heart pump known as an LVAD, Ryan said: “I am doing pretty well at the moment with the LVAD but waiting for a transplant can be hard. “I hope more people will discuss organ donation with their families and register their decision.”Anthony Clarkson of NHS Blood and Transplant said: “Thousands across the UK are waiting for the call that a donor has been found to save or transform their le.”Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSHospitalsHeart diseaseOrgan donationFluFitnessHeart transplantsDaily Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news man-says-takeaway-staff-laughed-"Diner left disgusted after finding a chicken foot in his takeawayByAaran LennoxJoe Smith:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A takeaway customer has described how staff ‘laughed and hung up the phone’ on him when he called to complain after finding a aposfootapos in his box of shredded salt and pepper chicken.The man said he was left feeling physically sick he has been put off chicken altogether following the grim find.The foot of the chicken can be seen encrusted in crunchy batter straight out of the fryer, in a photo he took of his takeaway meal.The shocked customer said he had just taken the first bite of his meal and had a mouthful of food when he saw the grisly appendage in his dinner, bought from East Eat, in Colwyn Bay. He said it has put him off visiting the establishment again.The customer, who wished to remain anonymous, contacted the takeaway to complain about the crispy foot find but he said they brushed him off and hung up the phone, North Wales Live reports. He said: I honestly didnapost even process it at first, I pulled out the first piece of chicken and took a bite. Following this I looked into the meal and noticed the oddly shaped piece, which made me put out what I had in my mouth in disbelief. As anyone would imagine seeing what I was holding on my hand really put me off the rest of my meal. I literally had to google chicken body parts to make sure I wasn’t telling myself it was what it wasn’t. But, then I knew and couldn’t continue eating the meal, I physically felt sick. After around  minutes of getting my head around what I had actually being served, I called the takeaway back and explained to them what had happened. I took photos and offered to send them to them to prove myself but they were having none of it. After trying to explain to them what they had served me, they just went silent, laughed, and then seconds later the line went dead”  He added: “I would have given them the benefit of the doubtthey had listened to me and took in what I was saying, and would have happily ed as a customer. I fully understand, they haven’t picked the pieces themselves and have just placed them in the fryer from a bag. The customer service really didn’t help matters on their behalf and the whole situation has confirmed to me that I will never enter the takeaway again, let alone order from there. This has put me off chicken as a whole, knowing that I could have eaten thatI hadnapost have noticed it. Chicken is no longer top of my choices of food, I would rather go withoutI’m being honest and will always opt for something the choices are there for me. Reporters contacted East Eat several times for a response and they have declined to comment.  The takeaway is currently awaiting afood hygiene ratingwhich is believed to have been delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Although chicken feet are often discarded as a waste product in the UK, they’re common cuisine in ious places around the world, including Mexico, South Africa, Asia, Jamaica, and Trinidad, where you can find them as street food or a festive dish. Chicken feet are praised for their health benefits, which are mostly attributed to their high collagen content. title: met office explains storm dudley
story: Met Office explains why Storm Dudley caused odd cloud formations like a paintingMammatus clouds appeared in the skies above Britain today after Storm Dudley hammered the country with mph winds, downing trees and knocking out power for thousands of BritsMammatus clouds have been spotted in the skies above Britain this evening Image: JontyFairless TwitterByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsStorm Dudley caused odd cloud formations to appear above the UK today. Curious Brits took to social media to share pictures of the distinctive pouch-like clouds, which one person likened to a painting.The phenomenon took place as mph winds lashed the country after the Met Office issued an amber weather warning for the north of the UK. Meteorologists have now answered Britsapos queries about the bizarre clouds that accompanied Storm Dudley. The organisation said the formations are called mammatus clouds. These clouds usually emerge after a storm has passed, particularly thunderstorms. They are named aposmammaapos, which means breast or udder in Latin, due to the apospouchesapos that appear underneath them. One awestruck Brit shared a snap of the clouds above the Scottish town of Clarkston, in East Renfrewshire. Another Twitter user, Claire Campbell, posted an image of the clouds above Glasgow. She said: I spotted these clouds during Storm Dudley today, at Silverburn ! Like a painting! Meanwhile Brian Morrison shared a video of the same aposweird cloudsapos above Glasgow. Another person wrote apos#StormDudley is doing weird things to the sky up in Edinburghapos and shared a picture of a red sky filled with mammatus clouds. Retweeting a video of the clouds, the Met Office said: Great Mammatus clouds from #StormDudley.The Met Office website states:are some of the most unusual and distinctive clouds formations with a series of bulges or pouches emerging from the base of a cloud. The shape of mammatus formations can y widely from the classic protruding shape, to a more elongated tube hanging from the cloud above.” The clouds are particularly eye-catching during sunsets, when they absorb the red light and take on a crimson colour. The formations came after Storm Dudley caused chaos across the UK, downing trees and knocking out power for thousands of households. Nearly , homes in Wigan, Greater Manchester, were left without electricity after strong winds caused an outage. Electricity North West previously warned the weather may damage overhead lines and the network operator has now dispatched engineers to fix the issue. The firm said power cuts have also taken place in towns and villages throughout Lancashire and Cumbria.  As of pm, Capel Curig in Wales had experienced gusts of up to mph, with Emley Moore in Yorkshire seeing mph winds, while Drumalbin in Scotland was hit by mph gales. Social media users shared images and videos of fallen trees, large waves smashing coastal areas, howling winds and rain sweeping through quiet roads and dark and gloomy skies, with some facing delays on public transport. Met Office forecaster Greg Dewhurst told the PA news agency: Weaposve seen Storm Dudley move in over the course of today with strong winds and heavy rain across northern parts of the country.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter This is a complete contrast to areas in the south which have been rather mild and calm for the most part, the temperature even reaching C in some areas. Exposed areas in Scotland, Northern Ireland, parts of Wales and northern England have seen wind speeds largely between  and mph but the worst affected areas have reached and even surpassed mph this afternoon. In terms of rainfall the highest weaposve seen in the past  hours is .mm in Low Laithes in west Yorkshire, which is a good amount for the time period. title: our home surrounded 30m trench
story: Our home is surrounded by m trench after we were told we had a leakVincenzo and Lisa Pranzo described their experience with United Utilities as "horrying" and a "nightmare" after they followed the advice of an employee which they claim turned out to be wrongVincenzo Pranzo with the gigantic trench Image: James Maloney Lancs LiveByRachel SloperFatima Aziz:,  Feb |commentsA family has been left with a gigantic -metre trench outside their home after they claim they were given the wrong advice by their water company about a leak. Vincenzo and Lisa Pranzo said their experience with United Utilities was a nightmare after they followed the advice of an employee which turned out to be wrong, they claim. They claim they were told aposyeah youaposve definitely got a leakapos. According to the family, a United Utilities inspector visited their Lancashire home on October , , and told Lisa that he was checking properties for leaks due to a recent spate of high water usage in the area. The inspector allegedly told Lisa she had a leak at the corner of her property near the house and said work needed to be carried out after checking the drive and surrounding areas of the property.She told Lancashire Live that when Vincenzo arrived home and had the situation explained to him, he said that in that specic part of the property there were no pipes, but the inspector reportedly assured them there was indeed a leak and he would investigate the matter. He said to us, aposyeah youaposve definitely got a leakapos, who am I to argue with someone who works for United Utilities and he is supposedly qualied, Lisa said. They came back and dug underneath the wall and thereaposs no water visible, but he listens and says aposyeah the leak is definitely under your houseapos so then obviously you go into panic mode. Heaposs explained to me, as the leakaposs under my property, United Utilities donapost fix it, Iaposm liable to fix that. United Utilities has said it is sorry Mrs Pranzo is disappointed with the service she has received and said it remains in contact with the couple. Their full response is at the bottom of this article.  The couple say they were given two options, they could dig a trench and get a stop tap with an insulated box fitted outside or pay £ for a company to use a mole - displacing the soil creating a bore instead of a trench. Days before Christmas, when the couple still hadnapost figured out how they would fix their leak, Vincenzo walked up to the top of the drive when his foot started sinking through the ground. As heaposs walking from the path onto the road, his foot almost sank into the stones- a sinkhole had kind of appeared at the front of the property, Lisa said.  Now we knew a pipe directly runs there because  years ago, the fitting that United Utilities used to branch it off from the supply blew and they had to dig it up and replace that. Weaposre thinking at the time, this is where the leak is, obviously thereaposs a large pool of water here. Looking to their eldest son who is a pipefitter, the family believed that the leak was due to a faulty pipe fitting. But, during a re-inspection, the couple were allegedly told that the leak was simply a random pool of water. Lisa said: He turned up laughing, heaposs not taking us on, heaposs telling me first, itaposs a random pool of water thataposs appeared- well Iaposve lived in this house for  years and Iaposve never seen, even in the most torrential rain, a random pool of water. My house is on an incline, the path is about cm higher than the front of the house. Heaposs then trying to tell me that the water thataposs pooled at the top of the path is due to the leak under the house. I said aposIaposm not being funny and Iaposm obviously not a plumber myself but water doesnapost run uphill.apos  Vincenzo and his son decided to dig up a hole in the path themselves to prove where the leak was coming from. Having removed all the water from the hole, they watched as the water soon filled the hole up once again showing that the water wasnapost coming from a source underneath the house but from the top of the driveway. Despite being able to show where the leak was coming from, Lisa says the inspector still refused to take on board what they had found, so the family decided to get Christmas out of the way and go back to the inspectoraposs original suggestion to dig up the trench in the new year. In doing so, Lisa says they would have been able to apply for the Lead Replacement Scheme which allows customers to receive a grant to pay for the replacement fixture. It states on the United Utilities website: Under the lead pipe replacement scheme, we may be able to offer a free like for like connection of a replacement water supply pipe , from your boundary to the water main in the road or footpath. Before going ahead, Vincenzo and Lisa asked the companythey were to dig, when would be the closest time they could come out and were told someone could come to replace the pipe in - days. My husband spent three weeks digging this trench that had to be cm deep and  metres long which is no mean feat in the freezing cold but he did it because there was going to be no other way we were going to be able to afford to do this, Lisa said. Then we got an email to say that it was now going to take - months to connect the water supply because there is a backlog at the council with applying for work permits. Explaining the severity of the leak and the now gaping hole across their drive, Lisa was able to arrange with the company for another inspection. The fella that came out, hats off to him - he was brilliant - I told him what the other fella had said and heaposs shaking his head, Lisa said. He said because lead pipes are such good conductors of sound, you could hear a leak right at the top and I could be hearing it from ,  metres down. He raised the job immediately and they were out the next morning- it took them an hour to dig down, find the leak which had nothing to do with my pipe, my pipe was fine. It was, as I said, the connection that United Utilities had put in - it was faulty, it was leaking - they fixed it. Although the leak was fixed, the trench was still there, which caused yet more problems for the family. During this time, Lisaaposs youngest, her -year-old son, badly hurt his foot on the rubble outside of their home and after an infection, he was put on antibiotics. He had to have adult antibiotics in tablet form and he couldnapost swallow them so we have to cut open the tablet to give him the power, Lisa said. The first two times he vomited in the kitchen floor because it was that bitter- he had to have that four times a day. While the cost of the job to repair the leak was covered by the company, Lisa said she rang up the customer service team hoping for some help with the trench they never needed to dig.  After  days of reportedly not getting a full response back, Lisa says she was told nothing could be done and she would have to fix the trench privately, with no option to speak to senior members of the team herself. Itaposs still not over because weaposre still arguing about it, Lisa said. Weaposve invested a lot of money in this house and itaposs one of the only things weaposve got of any worth and theyaposve made us do that to our home for no reason. The least they should have done is offer to help us put it straight - this is going to cost me money now for a skip, put the patios back and ordering sand and cement. My husband is working full-time and has to try and fit that in now around work- I just donapost think they understand what theyaposve done. He worked really hard and I feel for him, the words apos metre trenchapos donapost do any justice to the pictures and how hard he worked. Itaposs just been a nightmare from start to finish andUnited Utilities trained these people better who went round with these listening devices we wouldnapost be in this situation weaposre in now. Iaposve paid my water bill and I have been for the past  years to the water company, I am never late, Iaposve never once moaned or had a problem and I donapost get a phone call from the person who decided this.  United Utilities says their policy stands that private homeowners are responsible for the maintenance of water supply pipes that bring water into their homes from the mains on the street. Where customers have supply pipes made of lead, United Utilities advise them to replace them and there is a lead pipe replacement scheme the teams will point customers to where appropriate. A spokesperson for United Utilities said: We are sorry that Mrs Pranzo is disappointed with the service she has received. Whilst we will try to help customers when a leak has been identied on their property it is ultimately their responsibility to maintain the water supply pipe to their home. We are still in contact with the customer and we hope they will apply to our lead pipe replacement scheme that can help with grants for replacing lead supply pipes.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON United Utilities PLCCustomer service" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: parents joy baby opens eyes
story: Parents joy as baby opens her eyes after  days in intensive care following heart opPola Gapski was born in June  with Downs syndrome and a hole in her heart - she underwent an operation in January where she was kept in Alder Hey until she could go home in on February Pola underwent a gruelling surgery at just six-months-old to repair a hole in her heart Image: Rainbow TrustByAaliyah RuggAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsParents have shared their joy after their baby opened her eyes after spending  days in intensive care. When Olena Veitaite was five months pregnant she and partner Michael Gapski were told their daughter would need surgery to repair her heart after she was diagnosed with a cardiac condition - an atrioventricular septal defect. Pola was born in June  with Downaposs syndrome and a hole in her heart.The family were referred to leading charity Rainbow Trust before her surgery at Alder Hey, LiverpoolECHO reports. Pola underwent her operation in January when she was six months old to repair the hole in her heart.  The operation was meant to last six hours, but after eight hours the doctor wanted to speak to the parents. Olena, from Blackburn, said: The doctor explained the operation had been very complicated and Pola had had dficulty breathing because of pulmonary consolidation, meaning there was some blood in her lungs. She had to spend ten days in intensive care, initially with an open chest and on breathing machines. It was incredibly hard.  It took  days for Pola to open her eyes as the mum said she cried tears of joy when her daughter appeared to be out of the woods. She added: On  January she opened her eyes. It was amazing and we cried constantly with joy. Gradually she became stronger and the tubes were taken out of her belly and step by step she was getting better. Since September  the family has been supported by Rainbow Trust Family Support Worker, Brodie Stockwell. Olena added: Over time we became more and more comfortable with Brodie and now she feels like a part of the family.When we were in hospital Brodie would accompany me on the ward as only one parent was allowed because of Covid-. I was sleeping at the hospital and only swapping with Michael so that I could eat meals. It was exhausting and having Brodie was such a support.On February , little Pola was finally able to come home. Olena said: As we opened the front door carrying Pola, Michael and I looked at each other and started crying with happiness and relief. We were so thankful that we were coming home with our baby. We love Pola so much and throughout it all Michael and I have always tried to keep positive and Brodie has been such a help.” Rainbow Trust supports families who face the very real possibility that their child might die. To mark the Trustaposs th anniversary they are creating a permanent presence in Liverpool to help families like Polaaposs. Rainbow Trust Chief Executive Zillah Bingley added: For several years we have been aware that there are a number of families in desperate need for the type of support Rainbow Trust provides in and around Liverpool. Rainbow Trust has supported families attending Alder Hey for treatment, like Pola’s family, but until now we have not been able to fund a new team in the area. Thanks to the incredibly generous donation from The Kentown Wizard Foundation this is now a reality. We look forward to working alongside the existing palliative organisations in the region to ensure that our new team can complement the existing support and together make sure that families receive the full care they require. news uk-news prince-charles-harry-could-quizzed-"‘Cash-for-honours’ probe launched after Charles and ex-aide reported to policeByTom PettorCrime EditorRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb Prince Charles and Prince Harry could be quizzed as witnesses in a cash for honours investigation launched by Scotland Yard.The Prince of Wales and his former right-hand man Michael Fawcett were reported to police over a Saudi billionaire who made donations to royal charities, allegedly after he was promised a knighthood and British citizenship.In a move which could heap further misery on the Queen and Royal Family, the politan Police today announced it had launched a probe.The Prince of Wales, who presented Mahfouz Marei Mubarak bin Mahfouz with an honorary title at a private ceremony at Buckingham Palace in , has denied knowledge of the alleged deal.  The investigation emerged amid calls for transparency about Prince Andrew’s £million civil sex case settlement. The Mirror can reveal the Queen helped Prince Andrew settle the claim by making a £million donation to his sex abuse accuser’s charity. But ­questions were still being asked about whether public money was used. Her Majesty was today seen for the first time since her Covid scare last week, at an engagement at Windsor Castle. Standing with a walking stick, she pointed to her left leg or foot, and said: “Well, as you can see, I can’t move.” Tonight a source close to Charles confirmed the future king is willing to speak to police to help the investigation. They said: “There has been no request for help from the police so far, buthe is asked to help he will of course do so.” The allegations centre around ­businessman Mr Mahfouz donating £.million to restoration projects of particular interest to Prince Charles.  Mr Fawcett, who has since quit as chief executive of Charles’s charity, is alleged to have negotiated with fixers to secure a CBE for the Saudi who was said to be seeking recognition and residency in the UK infor financial contributions to The Prince’s Foundation. Prince Harry met Mr Mahfouz in  and was pictured shaking hands with the billionaire who donated £, to his charity.In December, the Sunday Times revealed that the pair met at a pub in Cha, West London, owned by Mark “Marko” Dyer, a former royal equerry known as Harry’s “second father”, who is said to have brokered the introduction in . They reportedly discussed Sentebale, a charity Harry set up after a gap year in Lesotho, Southern Africa. In response to the report, the Duke of Sussex issued a rare statement saying he had severed his ties with Mr Mahfouz. A spokeswoman for Prince Harry said: “The Duke and his advisers, as well as his nonprofit Sentebale, severed ties with Mr Mahfouz and his associates in , no longer accepting further donations to Sentebale and discontinuing any plans for a fundraising event amid growing concerns over his motives. “The Duke had one planned meeting with this donor nearly eight years ago, did not introduce him to any members of the Royal Family, and expressed concerns about the donor.”  Harry did not say what he believed Mahfouz’s motives were, or specy whether he shared his “concerns” with Charles or Clarence House. Despite the denials, former Met detective sergeant Steve Morris said: “Both Prince Charles and Prince Harry should be questioned without a doubt. “It is all part of the investigation, how the donor got to where he is within the charity, that is vital evidence to show the picture of how he has allegedly infiltrated the charity. “They should both be spoken to at the very least as witnesses. It would involve officers going to their address, or them being invited to a police station to give what’s called a Section  statement, purely as a witness at this moment in time.” Charles is president of the foundation but thought not to be involved with its governance or with trustees overseeing its day-to-day activities. A Clarence House spokesman said: “The Prince of Wales had no knowledge of the alleged offer of honours or British citizenship on the basis of donation to his charities.” Prince Harry could not be reached for comment. The Met is understood to have arranged an investigating team after pressure group Republic contacted Scotland Yard last September and reported Charles and Mr Fawcett on suspicion of breaching the HonoursAct . At the time Clarence House said the Prince had “no knowledge” of the alleged cash-for-honours scandal.Former BBC royal correspondent Peter Hunt tweeted: “This has the potential to be very challenging for Prince Charles. For decades, Michael Fawcett was one of his most powerful confidants.“If their investigation is to be ­credible, the Met police will have to interview the future king in the same way they would any other citizen.”  Mr Mahfouz has previously denied the allegations. Scotland Yard confirmed a probe is under way, saying: “The decision follows an assessment of a September  letter. This related to media reporting alleging offers of help were made to secure honours and citizenship for a Saudi national. The Special Enquiry Team has conducted the assessment process which has included contacting those believed to hold relevant information. “Officers liaised with The Prince’s Foundation about the findings of an independent investigation into fundraising ­practices. The foundation provided a number of relevant documents. “These were reviewed alongside existing information. The assessment determined an investigation will commence. There have been no arrests or interviews under caution.” Read MoreRead More Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince HarryPrince Andrew, Duke of YorkPrince Charles, Prince of WalesBBCBuckingham PalaceScotland Yardpolitan PoliceCharitiesRoyal FamilyBillionairesDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: savvy mum transforms kitchen herself
story: Savvy mum transforms kitchen herself for £ after being quoted a whopping £,After being quoted a whopping £, for a kitchen renovation Jill Oliver decided to take matters into her own hands and transform her kitchen herself for less than £Jill Oliver spent only £ on her redecoration Image: LatestDealsByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A savvy mum has transformed her kitchen on a budget for only £ after she was quoted a massive £,.Jill Oliver wanted to makeover her kitchen but renovations were slapped with a massive price tag for any changes she wanted to make. The mum from Durham didn’t let her stop that though and took things into her own hands.She documented her efforts on a Facebook group ‘DIY On a Budget UK’, it was reported on LatestDeals. She said: I painted my kitchen in the first lockdown with a dark grey paint as I had seen other people do this but I loved the shaker style kitchens. I just followed lots of home accounts and saw dferent people doing similar things.We had quotes a while back and it ied but it would have been something like £, to replace the kitchen and I couldn’t justy that kind of money when I knew I could update the plain doors to a shaker style myself.” After using MDF, a medium weight fibreboard, in her bedroom for ling as well as on her staircase and hallway, Jill was already self-taught. She continued: I was desperate to do my kitchen and after doing the hall I knew I could do my kitchen. So I contacted a local timber merchant and asked them to cut a sheet of MDF into mm strips, which meant it would cover all the old holes where the handles had been. I chose mm deep as I tried dferent depths of MDF and any thicker it would have caught on the door next to it.”  She cut eachwith a manual saw and asked her local timber merchant to cut a sheet of MDF into mm strips. Jill said: “ I did three light coats with a sponge roller. I used the Valspar v eggshell paint for wood and metal. “It was colour matched to Farrow and Ball Purbeck stone.” She then drilled holes for the doorknobs and replaced the door hinges with soft close hinges so they don’t bang when they close.Jill uploaded the upcycled kitche to her Instagram account which has received more than , views. She concluded: It cost me £ for the MDF, about £ for the primer and eggshell paint and about £ for the new handles and a couple of pounds each for the caulk and adhesive. I have friends who paid about £, at least to have their kitchens professionally painted and that didn’t include changing them with the MDF. People are frightened to try so my advice would be to try painting a little piece of furniture first to get used to painting oryou have a spare kitchen cupboard stuck in the loft then have a little practice on that. “Obviously saving the money is a huge benefit and that means I have that money to spend somewhere .” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Kitchen" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: schools advised charity drop sir
story: Schools advised by charity to drop Sir and Miss in gender inclusivity driveThe Educate and Celebrate charity told teachers during a training session that pupils and staff could adopt terms like ‘child’, ‘pupils’ and ‘students’ to be more acceptingCommon ways of referring to educators, such as ‘Mr’, ‘Sir’, ‘Miss’ or ‘Mrs’ could be replaced by the gender-neutral ‘Teacher’ Dr Elly Barnes said during the union-funded training Image: Getty ImagesByFinn Byrne:,  Feb |comments A debate over the use of gender neutral-terms in schools has been sparked after a charity group encouraged teachers and pupils to ditch certain words.The Educate and Celebrate charity told teachers during a training session that pupils and staff could adopt terms like ‘child’, ‘pupils’ and ‘students’ to be more accepting.Common ways of referring to educators in schools, such as ‘Mr’, ‘Sir’, ‘Miss’ or ‘Mrs’ could be replaced by the gender-neutral ‘Teacher’ Dr Elly Barnes said during the union-funded training.The charity leader suggested neutral replacements for ‘boys’, ’girls’, ‘son’ and ‘mother’ such as ‘pupils’, ‘students’ and ‘child’.A list of alternative words and terms were shown to teachers at the training session, with other examples of neutral language including ‘head pupil’ instead of ‘head boy’ and ‘parent’ rather than ‘mother’, reports MyLondon. During the -minute lecture, which was organised by the National Education Union , Dr Barnes outlined how schools should be moving towards a ‘gender free model’. The charity leader told the group that her ideas were working well in schools where it had already been implemented. Barnes showed attendees a ‘code of conduct’ that she encouraged schools to display at reception. The poster listed bullet points of all the characteristics protected under the Equalities Act, apart from sex. Barnes suggested that the options of ‘male’ and ‘female’ should be removed from school application forms, with a box for gender simply ‘left open’ instead. One attendee reportedly argued that teachers ‘do not take offence’ from words such as ‘Sir’ or ‘Miss’, saying they are only used to ‘get your attention’. news uk-news storm-dudley-met-office-red-"Storm Dudley: Trampoline blown on to the train tracks near CardfByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsThe Met Office remains on red alert after Storm Dudley’s powerful winds destroyed homes and cut power for thousands of Brits - with a second storm set to hit the country. Millions of Brits endured a fretful night as huge gusts of around mph battered parts of the UK, with amber warnings in place for central Scotland, Northern Ireland and in England.  Commuters looking to get to work this morning have woken to roads blocked by felled trees as well as nightmares of train lines as workers try to remove the devastation. People on social media shared pictured of damaged homes, crushed cars and power cuts. In the north of England, around , were left without power with thousands still waiting for the lights to be turned on.  As Storm Dudley arrived on Wednesday afternoon, Capel Curig in Wales experienced gusts of up to mph, with Emley Moore in Yorkshire seeing mph winds, while Drumalbin in Scotland was hit by mph gales. Workers are also doing their best to improve conditions before Storm Eunice arrives on Friday with fears the second named storm in days could be even worse with predicted in winds in excess of mph in coastal areas and around mph in others. Earlier it was reported the Met Office could be set to put out a rare red alert. Met Office forecaster Marco Petagnasaid: Thereaposs obviously been a generally blustery picture across the country with a combination of rain and hill snow in the north. Some areas have seen severe gusts of up to mph so itaposs been a very windy day but that will start to slowly ease as we go into tomorrow.  A new yellow warning of snow and ice has been issued for northern parts of Scotland and is expected to last into Thursday morning which could create some dangerous conditions on roads and paths. Electricity North West said power cuts were affecting nearly , homes in Wigan and thousands more around Lancashire. National Rail said as of am Thursday, dozens of train companies have been affected in the north of England, the Midlands, Wales and across most of Scotland, including LNER, Transport for Wales and ScotRail. It added that due to damage to the overhead electric wires between Bedford and St Albans, some lines are currently blocked on the East Midlands Railway and Thameslink lines.  Network Rail engineers are checking more than , miles of Scotlandaposs railway while ScotRail warned services will not run until the lines have been cleared as safe to reopen- at least am. ScotsRail tweeted: Due to the early shut down following #StormDudley weaposre doing our best to get our services back up and running as quickly as possible. Yesterday several people posted pictures of a train which had collided with a trampoline near Cardf, causing delays of around two hours for travellers.  As @networkrailscot engineers continue to do safety checks our services will not run until the lines have been cleared as safe to re-open. Ferry passengers also faced disruption. Scotlandaposs Deputy First Minister John Swinney warned that the coming days will be very challenging as a result of Storm Dudley and the expectation of Storm Eunice on Friday.  He said: We expect another period of disruption this week, with storms Dudley and Eunice set to bring strong winds to Scotland.” Strange clouds resembling jellyfish were spotted by some across the country and shared online. Brian Morrison filmed the bulbous formation called Mammatus. It is a rare and spectacular phenomenon which is the result of a process best described as reverse direction conviction.  Meanwhile, the Environment Agency has warned of the risk of flooding in southern England on Friday. Flood duty manager Katharine Smith said: Strong winds could bring coastal flooding to parts of the west, south-west and south coast of England, as well as the tidal River Severn, through the early hours of Friday morning and into the early afternoon. This is due to Storm Eunice resulting in high waves and potential storm surge coinciding with the start of a period of spring tides.  National Highways have issued a severe weather alert for strong winds covering the East of England, East Midlands, West Midlands, South East and South West, between the hours of am and pm on Friday. The agency added there is high risk that high-sided vehicles and other aposvulnerableapos vehicles such as caravans and motorbikes could be blown over in areas including the East of England, Midlands, South East and South West. As a result of Storm Eunice, The Queenaposs , acre Sandringham Estate is set to be closed to the public amid fears of falling trees.In a statement, Sandringham said The safety of visitors and staff is our priority.We will continue to monitor the forecasts and will carry out any necessary safety checks prior to reopening visitor facilities on Saturday, February .  Green Flag has predicted a spike in breakdowns across the country over the coming days. Mark Newberry, commercial director at Green Flag, said: As a result of these weather conditions, we urge drivers to remain cautious and to carry out the relevant safety checks before setting off on their journeys. Itaposs particularly important that people are as prepared as possible to withstand the high expected wind speeds and potential snow in some areas. title: the queen always puts duty
story: The Queen always puts duty first, even after Royal Family rocked by scandalsAfter Prince Andrews court case scandal, Scotland Yard announced it is launching a criminal probe into an alleged cash for honours scandal at the heart of one of Prince Charles’s charitiesQueen Elizabeth II speaks during an audience at Windsor Castle Image: PAopinionByRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Feb Sex scandals, secret payoffs and police probes should be more at home in the latest Martina Cole novel than the daily lives of the Royal Family - and yet here we are. Just when The Firm thought they had buried one of the most shameful and humiliating periods in its recent history, the Queen has been dealt another hammer blow. Scotland Yard launching a criminal probe into an alleged cash for honours scandal at the heart of one of Prince Charles’s charities is not just another extraordinary development in exceptional times. It may call into question the very fabric of those operating at the heart of the monarchy.  Once again, as she has done many times before in times of trouble, the Queen today summoned the strength to put on a brave face and put duty first. But one could not fail to be moved by her admission, walking stick in hand, that she was unable to move as she would wish while a dignitary was wheeled out for a photo-op at her Windsor home. Just as she should be preparing to revel in the glory of her remarkable  years on the throne, it seems as though events are imploding around her. The family had hoped the shame of Prince Andrew’s involvement with two convicted sex offenders would be finalised ahead of Her Majesty’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations this year. But questions will surely remain over the Queen’s judgment in helping her son make such a settlement to his sex abuse accuser, which largely remains shrouded in secrecy. All of this against a backdrop of another potential scandal, which may see her son Charles and grandson Prince Harry quizzed by police, albeit as witnesses in the first instance. If ever there was a time to unite and collectively take the strain, now is that time for the family. Whether they are too fractured to do so is a story to be continued. story: TikTok star and two other women accused of A double murder in courtTikTok star Mahek Bukhari, , her mother, Ansreen Bukhari, , and Natasha Akhtar, , are charged in relation to the deaths of Saqib Hussain and Mohammed Hashim Ijazuddin, both TikTok star Mahek Bukhari is charged in relation to the deaths Image: InstagramBySuzy Gibson:,  Feb Three women accused of murdering two young men who died in a crash on the A in Leicestershire have appeared in court. TikTok star Mahek Bukhari, , her mum, Ansreen Bukhari, , and Natasha Akhtar, , are charged in relation to the deaths of Saqib Hussain and Mohammed Hashim Ijazuddin, both , whose silver Skoda Fabia crashed through the central reservation on the A carriageway, near the junction of Six Hills, at .am on Friday February .The two men, from Oxfordshire, were pronounced dead at the scene, Leicestershire Live reports. Leicestershire Police confirmed that two other cars, a grey Audi TT and a blue Seat Leon, were also travelling in the area at the same time.  Mahek Bukhari and Ansreen Bukhari, both of Stoke-on-Trent, and Akhtar, of Birmingham, appeared at Leicester Crown Court this morning via a live video link from HMP Peterborough. All three were wearing protective face masks while sitting next to each other, with Mahek Bukhari in the middle. Each acknowledged their names when addressed by the court clerk. There were no applications for bail during the  minute preliminary hearing.The prosecutor, James House QC, told Judge Timothy Spencer QC that two men had also been charged in connection with both alleged murders and were due to appear in the cityaposs magistrates court today. All five defendants are expected to attend a crown court plea and case management hearing on Friday, March . A provisional six week trial date was earmarked for Monday, September . story: What is Deltacron  Hybrid Omicron and Delta Covid iant found in UK being monitoredA new iant of Covid- dubbed Deltacron has been detected by a UK health agency that is said to exhibit characteristics of previous forms of the virus - heres what we know so farA new Covid iant that is a hybrid of the Omicron and Delta has been identied in the UK, but numbers are currently low Image: PAByHarry ThompsonTrends WriterNeil Shaw:,  Feb |comments A new iant of coronavirus has been found in the UK, with the country’s Health Security Agency now monitoring how it develops. The news comes after the UK has had to tolerate two years of Covid , with multiple iants like Omicron, Delta and Alpha taking it in turns to cause havoc, lock down the country and claim the lives of thousands of people. With signs emerging that Omicron is beginning to recede, the government has begun to dramatically scale back restrictions over the UK.In the biggest change yet, mandatory isolation for people who test positive for the virus is due to be lted on February . What is the new Covid iant   It has been labelled ‘Deltacron’ after seemingly exhibiting aspects of the Omicron and Delta iants that have, at dfering points, ripped through the UK. Its scientic name is BA. + B....Experts have reported it has developed in patients who caught both Omicron and Delta at the same time,WalesOnlinereports.The UK Health Security Agency, or UKHSA, is yet to deliver a verdict on how contagious this form of the virus is, or how dangerous it could be for people who catch it.According to theMail , the UKHSA is yet to announce how many cases of the hybrid have been found in the country.Professor Paul Hunter, an infectious diseases expert at the University of East Anglia, told MailOnline: If both Delta and Omicron are falling then, in theory, this [iant] should struggle to take off. Covid iants that are products of recombination are rare but have been known to form at points throughout the pandemic - three cases have arisen in the past with hundreds having been infected. Speaking to the MailOnline, a UKHSA source said: We monitor everything as a matter of course, but we are not particularly anxious about this iant. The developments have led to Deltacron being included in the UKHSA’s iant surveillance report.Indiareports that the iant was initially believed to be a laboratory error, however, its inclusion in the report has signalled that the iant is real.The same publication reports that the UKHSA is yet to report whether the iant was imported to the UK or whether it is native. The Mail report that sources at the UKHSA is “not concerned” by the iant with case numbers remaining low. The findings are contextualised by generally positive news about Covid, with the number of people who have tested positive up to February  having fallen by ,, or .%, in the last seven days. news uk-news whats-next-prince-andrew-calls-"Prince Andrew: What’s next for Duke after Giuffre settlement ByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Feb Prince Andrew has now reached an out of court settlement with his accuser Virginia Giuffre in a civil sex claim filed in the US. It means that he has now avoided a potentially explosive trial with the settlement said to be £million.In the past two years since giving a car crash interview on BBC Newsnight about his association with the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, Andrewaposs le has changed dramatically. Shortly after the sit-down interview, he sensationally quit public le - announcing it in a statement that was approved by the Queen.Meanwhile, just last month, the Duke of York was stripped of all his military affiliations and royal patronages by his mother the monarch. The statement from Buckingham Palace also said he would continue not to undertake any public duties. Now the civil claim against him has been settled, what could be next for Andrew  We take a look... Public roleThis year, Andrewaposs mother the Queen is celebrating her Platinum Jubilee after marking  years on the throne.In June, there will be a host of celebrations on a bumper four-day long bank holiday weekend. So will we see Andrew at these events or indeed carry out public duties in the future now a settlement has been agreed According to former BBC royal correspondent Jennie Bond, absolutely not. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .She told the Mirror: The Queen has already assured the smooth transition of the monarchy by expressing her wish for Camilla to be Queen alongside Prince Charles. And the new King will want a streamlined modern monarchy in which Andrew was already surplus to requirements. He is, of course, a much-loved son and is adored by his ex-we, Fergie, and their two daughters. He will remain part of the royal family into which he was born, and I am sure the Queen will include him in family le. But there can be no public role for him ever again.  The fact is that Prince Andrew will forever remain tarnished by more than a decade of speculation about his friendship with a convicted paedophile.However, a report last week suggested Andrew could make a public appearance at a remembrance service for his late father Prince Philip next month.Sources told the Sun Andrew is expected at the ceremony at Westminster Abbey on March .Duke of York title stripped   While Andrew may have been stripped of his military affiliations and his royal patronages - he still retains his Duke of York title.And even though the civil claim been settled, he is facing renewed calls to give up his ducal title. Labour MP Rachael Maskell, who represents York Central, says Andrew must remove his association with the city in light of the out-of-court settlement reached with Virginia Giuffre. She added that she welcomed the Duke of York’s pledge to donate money to his accuser’s charity, but said his relationship with disgraced Jeffrey Epstein had damaged the city’s reputation. She said: “Although it is a relief that Prince Andrew has finally acknowledged and expressed regret for his close association with a convicted sex offender and sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein, his long delay in doing so and initial response to the charges and Ms Giuffre have been source of deep hurt and embarrassment to many people across the city. “Carrying a title does create an ambassadorial relationship with that place, and for somewhere with a global reputation, such as York, this is extremely important.  “It is to be welcomed that he has now pledged to support the fight against the evils of sex trafficking and its victims. “To demonstrate his seriousness in this endeavour, and his respect for those affected by abuse and the people of our city, I would ask that his first act of contrition is to confirm his support for the withdrawal of his ducal title.” Quoting a poll from York’s daily newspaper The Press, she highlighted how  per cent of people in the city who were asked wanted Andrew’s association with it to be removed. Helping sex trafficking victims   In court documents filed yesterday indicating a settlement had been agreed, a statement was included in a letter submitted to US judge Lewis A Kaplan, who has been overseeing the civil sex claim brought by Ms Giuffre.In it, Andrew admitted his regret at his association with Jeffrey Epstein and also vowed to support sex trafficking victims. Part of the statement said: It is known that Jeffrey Epstein trafficked countless young girls over many years. “Prince Andrew regrets his association with Epstein, and commends the bravery of Ms. Giuffre and other survivors in standing up for themselves and others. “He pledges to demonstrate his regret for his association with Epstein by supporting the fight against the evils of sex trafficking, and by supporting its victims.”  However, Nazir Afzal, a former chief prosecutor, has said that he has spoken with many sexual attack victims and claims they have told him they would not work with Andrew.Writing in the Mirror, he said: Victims have been so badly affected by the language his legal team has been using I cannot think any of them will want to be in the same room as him. I’m patron of nine charities working with victims of sex offending. However, he added: I’m happy to offer him the opportunity to meet victims, in confidence, to understand their suffering and how victim-blaming of the type he indulged in will have affected them. news uk-news you-need-know-after-covid-"JCVI updates advice on vaccinations for five to -year-oldsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments All children over five in England will be able to get a coronavirus vaccine from April, the Government announced today. Two smaller doses of the Pfizer jab,  weeks apart, will be available to this age group to help control future Covid waves after Covid curbs have been lted.Professor Wei Shen Lim, Covid chair of the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation , said: The Committee has carefully considered the potential direct health impacts of vaccination and potential indirect educational impacts.The main purpose of offering vaccination to --year-olds is to increase their protection against severe illness in advance of a potential future wave of Covid-.Here is all you need to know...  What is the advice  The JCVI advice is for parents of --year-olds to get them vaccinated “ they feel comfortable” to protect against possible future Covid waves. They fear that should a new iant trigger a wave, at that point it will be too late to get all children in this age group protected by vaccination in time. The very small chance of severe complications in this age group is thought to be bigger than the even smaller chance of severe vaccine side effects. Some % of - year olds are thought to have already had Covid, however immunity wanes over time, particularly against mild infection.  What is dferent about this advice  While the independent experts advise that this age group should have the jab, the JCVI have issued a more nuanced message and stress it is not an emergency programme like previous vaccine drives. They say parents should not rush to get them vaccinated against Covid at the expense of school time or other childhood vaccinations such as the MMR jab. In the older  to  age group so far . million have received at least one dose.  What was considered when deciding to recommend jabs for this age group  While school absences were considered this was not a signicant factor. This was because pupils can require time off with mild side effects - such fever, headache or sore arm - as well as requiring time off due to Covid. The main factor was the risk of serious illness to the child. The JCVI weighed up the extremely low risk of severe Covid symtoms versus the extremely low risk of severe vaccine side effects.  What is my child’s risk  In a future Covid wave between  and  cases of a rare inflammatory condition called PIMS-TS triggered by Covid will be prevented for every million double vaccinated - year olds. The JCVI also estimates that between  and  Covid hospitalisations will be prevented per million double jabbed in this age group, as well as up to three ICU admissions. This was compared to the risk of the most worrying vaccine side effect of Covid- vaccines, known as myocarditis. This is inflammation of the heart muscle and it is still unclear how harmful it is in the long term. The JCVI estimates it occurs in less than two per million children given the Pfizer jab.  How will rollout work It is yet to be decided whether vaccines will be administered to - year olds in schools or NHS centres.From April this age group will be offered two  micrograms doses of the Pfizer vaccine This is much less than the  microgram doses given to adults. They will be administered at least  weeks apart but the second dose may be delayed so it can be administered during school holidays. This is to avoid school absences caused by minor side effects such as fever, headache and sore arm. story: First Victorias Secret model with Downs syndrome says her dreams have come truePuerto Rican model Sofia Jirau, who made her debut at New York Fashion Week, has called it a "dream come true" to become the first Victorias Secret model with Downs syndromeThe Puerto Rican model Sofia Jirau makes history as the first Victorias Secret model with Down syndrome Image: NewsflashByLee BullenJoe Smith:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A woman has celebrated making history by becoming the first model with Downaposs syndrome to pose for Vocitria’s Secret. Sofia Jirau, a -year-old Puerto Rican model and activist told followers she is taking part in the American lingerie brandaposs new Love Cloud campaign - advertising the collection of everyday underwear. Sofia’s career has been gathering steam since she made her catwalk debut at New York Fashion Week in February  and she has been attracting the attention of the fashion industry throughout the pandemic.She took to social media to share her delight at posing for Victoria’s Secret, calling it ‘a dream come true’ but some online commenters have raised concerns about sexualising people with Down’s syndrome, saying they had ‘mixed emotions’ about the campaign. Victoria’s Secret has launched a string of initiatives over the past few years to try and regain credibility in the face of declining sales and past accusations of a culture of misogyny at the business.Recent moves by the company include its first mastectomy bra, racially erse models promoting underwear in dferent skin tones, and hiring transgender beauty Valentina Sampaio after being criticised for its lack of ersity. Victoria’s Secret as previously branded a apostransphobic, fat phobic company that sets out to exclude most womenapos, by TV star Jameela Jamil while shop closures and the cancelling of its high-profile catwalk showcase have added to the companyaposs woes in recent years.Celebrating the news of her campaign today on Instagram, Sofia said: aposOne day I dreamed of it, I worked on it and today it is a dream come true. I can finally tell you my big secret… I am the first Victoriaaposs Secret model with Downaposs syndrome.aposSharing a black and white picture of her modelling the brandaposs bra, she continued: aposThanks to all of you for always supporting me in my projects. Thanks to @victoriassecret for seeing me as a #NoLimits model and making me part of the Love Cloud Collection inclusion campaign. This is just the beginning, now itaposs formed.apos aposInside and out there are no limits, Alavett,apos she said, quoting her own brand, which is named after the English phrase aposI love it.apos Sofia shared a black and white snap of herself wearing a floral balcony bra from the brand with her , followers. As well as modelling, she works as an activist with her No Limits campaign, called Sin Límites, which aims to raise awareness about Down’s Syndrome.  Sofia also founded her own brand, Alavett, launching its online store in . She came to global attention when she made her catwalk debut at New York Fashion Week in February . She said she hoped her success would inspire other people with Down’s. Speaking at the time she said: “I am proud as one of the few models with Downaposs syndrome who have managed to participate in the important fashion event. “Modelling in the United States was the beginning of conquering the dream I have had since an early age - to model on the most important runways in the world.”  Victoria’s Secret launched their Love Cloud collection on Monday designed to be comfortable everyday underwear as part of their ongoing efforts to rebrand. The campaign sees  women modelling the range, some are professional models while others are inspiring women, to reinforce the message that the brand is for everyone. The inclusive campaign features Celilo Miles, a Nez Perce Tribe-Wildland firefighter and Sylvia Buckler, an accessory designer who models the bra while cradling her pregnant belly. Speaking to Vogue, Celilo said she still cannot believe she was selected for the campaign. aposI used to watch the Victoriaaposs Secret fashion show and wish that I could be up on that stage. aposEveryone wanted to be in that club, but you knew you didn’t belong there, she said. She added that when she started modelling she tried to lose weight in order to fit a size she could not sustain because she believed it was the done thing.
