FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBronagh Murray with her lawyer Brian ArcherAllan PrestonTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA Co Down woman who won a religious and sexual discrimination case against the Ministry of Defencehas told of how months of insults by an Army captain left her dreading the thought of going to work.Bronagh Murray , a Catholic civilian worker who was stationed in Thiepval Barracks in Lisburn, is set to receive over £, in compensation after the decision of a Fair Employment Tribunal in Belfast this week. It is believed to be one of the largest awards of its kind, with the MoD also accepting liability.Read MoreCatholic woman who left job over alleged harassment by her Army boss to receive more than £, compensationSpeaking to the Belfast , Ms Murray said she was relieved at the decision and was now focused on rebuilding her le.I absolutely dreaded going to work even though I had an immaculate record as a civil servant since I was , she said.“At times I just couldn’t think straight. I thought I had a handle on it by ignoring him but I obviously didn’t. I kept thinking, ‘he’s getting the message, it just needs to stop’. I didn’t approach him at the time about the harassment because I felt I wouldn’t be believed and it would lead to more harassment because I didn’t find him funny.The harassment by the Army captain, who cannot be named for security reasons, took place over a five-month period in , with Ms Murray later retiring due to deteriorating psychiatric condition in .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The tribunal heard that the captain repeatedly referenced her religion in front of others and had also referred to her as “the big cougar”.In one incident, he was reported to have said: “I need back up, I have an Irish Catholic girl armed and dangerous, come quick, need help.”During an office conversation about a concert, it’s also claimed that he said: “I bet you have tried to steal a cone, that is the Catholic coming out in you.”After starting the complaint process in September , the captain was eventually disciplined and transferred to another military posting.The tribunal awarded Ms Murray around £, to cover injury to feelings, psychiatric injuries, loss of previous earnings and interest. Not due to retire until , compensation for loss of future earnings was calculated in excess of £,.She added: “I’m just so relieved and pleased with the outcome. I feel great because I’m totally vindicated and at long last the truth has come out.”She said the admission of liability from the MoD was particularly important.I didn’t ask for any of this, I had every intention of working until retirement age. Because of what happened to me, my health broke down and I was left with no other option than to go through the process of ill health retirement.“It was just so stressful, it was a horrible feeling. I had confided in a few close friends who knew what I was going through. It was such a hard time.”She said finding the courage to eventually speak up had felt like a major risk at the time.“I was afraid I wouldn’t be taken seriously, especially the cougar comment, she said.“I know a lot of people, even women, can find that funny, but I don’t. He just came out with it, he had been talking about someone looking for me ‘because you’re a big cougar’. I nearly fell off the chair. I just don’t find that funny or acceptable. It was a horrible feeling, the worst thing to say to a woman.“On every occasion that he did say something, I was at my desk typing or doing my admin work. I didn’t ask for this, he came to me to insult me.”Askedshe felt the insults were down to vindictiveness or just immaturity, she replied: “I really don’t know what he was thinking. It just beggars belief what was going through his head. All I wanted was to do my job and head home, but I was absolutely dreading it.Ms Murray also thanked her legal team, solicitor Brian Archer and barrister Michael Potter, for their “total support” title: plan for social housing beside belfasts st georges market refused after swathe of objections
story: St George’s Market in Belfast  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSt George’s Market in Belfast Michael Kenwood, Local Democracy ReporterFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA plan for a block of social housing and office space beside St George’s Market has been refused, after a swathe of local objections.Belfast City Council’s Planning Committee voted against the plan at this week’s meeting while council officers recommended the developer make a fresh application after months of delays over the proposal due to local opinion.Habinteg Housing Association had forwarded a plan to demolish the existing hostel building to provide a four-storey building comprising  social housing units, office space and ancillary development at Verner Street, which runs alongside the west side of St George’s Market.The council received  objections to the proposal, as well as letters of objection from Botanic district electoral area representatives, SDLP councillor Gary McKeown and Sinn Fein councillor John Gormley.A council officer told the committee: “The issues raised included a lack of community consultation, the proposal retaining as much of built heritage as possible as opposed to demolition of the building, and the density and size of the proposed residential units. There was concern the new residential units would not be fit for families.”She added other issues included lack of amenity space, overshadowing, particularly to the lower apartments, and fire safety concerns.Mr Gormley told the committee: “I don’t believe the proposal in front of members today is the right one. It risks undermining the very engagement to which the council has committed itself.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up I believe it should be rejected, leaving the door open for the developer and the community to come together to discuss and resolve the acknowledged flaws in this application.”David Worthington, a representative from the Markets Development Association, told the committee the proposal involves “wholly substandard areas of open space,” and apartments that would “experience constant overshadowing and inadequate light levels.”He said: “It has been said the proposal doesn’t really need any more private open space because it is close to the Waterfront, City Hall and other open spaces in the city centre. Those are all public open spaces – private open space is essential in all residential developments, and the minimum requirement is  square metres per apartment.”He added: “The message is you are being asked to set aside the regular rules, because this is social housing, and so it should be approved that those rules shouldn’t apply to it. The trouble with this is, you are essentially being told that social housing is second class housing.”Sinn Fein councillor Matt Garrett proposed the committee reject the plan, and this was unanimously story: Booked up: Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey and Lord Mayor of Belfast Kate Nicholl at the launch of the Feile an Earraigh Spring Programme at the James Connolly Visitor Centre. Credit: Colm Lenaghan FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBooked up: Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey and Lord Mayor of Belfast Kate Nicholl at the launch of the Feile an Earraigh Spring Programme at the James Connolly Visitor Centre. Credit: Colm LenaghanRalph HewittTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe team behind west Belfast’s Feile an Earraigh have promised the biggest ever line-up as the annual spring festival was launched yesterday.The launch took place at The James Connolly Visitor Centre on the Falls Road, with speakers including Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey, Belfast Lord Mayor Kate Nicholl, and Arts Council Chief Executive Roisin MacDonough.Feile an Phobail director Kevin Gamble spoke at the launch and explained that over  events will take place at the festival.“Feile an Earraigh is programmed to coincide with the celebration of our patron saint, St Patrick,” he said.“This year’s Feile an Earraigh delivers a wonderful mix of traditional music, concerts, talks, tours, book launches, family events, International Women’s Day events, and St Patrick’s Day related arts and cultural events.“At Feile an Earraigh, it’s not just about the tunes — it’s also about the warm and welcoming atmosphere that awaits locals and visitors alike.”Communities Minister Ms Hargey said she was extremely pleased to welcome the fullof the festival after the Covid- pandemic.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “This year, I am particularly delighted to launch this full programme of events which reaches out to everyone — our local community, our visitors and the wider international audience,” she said. “It is important that my department supports this festival.“The range of events in the programme showcases what we have to offer — the talent, the energy, and the creativity of those who, through performance, celebrate our arts and contribute to our social, economic and cultural fabric.“We all know the importance of the arts and the transformative role they can play in communities — engaging minds at an early age, respecting ersity, building social cohesion.“I look forward to attending the festival and I am proud to continue to do what I can to support Feile and the arts.”This year’s festival will take place Patrick’s sister Charley was their surrogate and they used a donor egg.It was a long and expensive process for the family, with heartache along the way after a first pregnancy ended in miscarriage. There were also delays caused by the pandemic.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClosePatrick and Jon Coyle with baby Wren, who was conceived using a donor egg and carried by Patrick’s sister Charley FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePatrick and Jon Coyle with baby Wren, who was conceived using a donor egg and carried by Patrick’s sister CharleyShortly before Wren was tucked into bed at the family home, Patrick and Jon told this newspaper about the emotional moment Charley offered to carry their baby five years ago.Patrick, who had assumed that fostering or adoption was their only choice, said: “We didn’t really think this would ever be an option for us. “We’d heard of people going to America for surrogacy but had heard it could cost , . That was something we could only dream of. She told us her thoughts on it, how her family and her partner felt about it and how it would be for her children.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseBaby Wren FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBaby WrenThe couple had considered using an egg donor clinic in Kiev but were encouraged to advertise in a local newspaper.They were stunned when they received a reply after a week, with the donor stipulating the egg should go to a gay couple. They subsequently attended a clinic in Belfast, with all family members having to go through counselling.Patrick said: “It was actually a really good gateway to open up questions that you might not have wanted to ask.“Charley [was] telling her children what way we would do things when she had the baby. “[We were asking], ‘Whatthere’s something wrong the baby  Who would decide what happens ”Jon said the couple were also prepared for facing intrusive questions about who the father of the baby was.“Who would ask that  But I’m sure plenty of people will be thinking it without saying it, so how do you manage people’s expectations ” he asked.Patrick added: “But the way the counsellor put it, why would we tell anyone who Wren’s ‘real’ daddy was before she knew “But it doesn’t matter. We’re both her daddy regardless of what has happened. “There’s loads of dferent ways to make a family. Just because ours is a little bit dferent doesn’t make it any less of a family.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClosePatrick’s sister Charley FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePatrick’s sister Charley“It also prepared us to tell people that it wasn’t a very nice question. And a lot of people did ask, ‘Whose sperm did you use ’”Jon added: “It’s a natural reaction, but we can tell people the boundaries about that. I have to say it was nieces and nephews that were the easiest to tell because they just accepted it.”Patrick said that Charley’s then three-year-old daughter was quick to correct anyone who congratulated her mum for becoming pregnant.He explained: “She would turn and say to them, ‘She’s not pregnant. That’s Jon and Patrick’s baby’. Charley would be killing herself laughing.”After the “heart wrenching” pain of losing the first pregnancy, Patrick faced dark timesHe recalled: “I was in turmoil some of the times, but when you look back, it was all just washed away when Wren was here.”When the couple announced the new pregnancy, their families were delighted. Jon said: “I had never seen our parents and siblings cry with that kind of joy — they couldn’t believe it.”The day of Wren’s birth was a “surreal” experience filled with hope but also concern.But they had little reason to worry because after Wren was born just before am, the new family was at home together by dinner time.Jon said: “On that drive home and going into the house, you’re thinking, Credit: Liam McBurneySuzanne BreenTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailColum Eastwood has accused Sinn Fein of focusing on selfish party interests rather than improving the lives of ordinary people.The SDLP leader said his rival’s -year record in government was abysmal, and while the party had engaged in radical rhetoric, it had failed to deliver.Speaking ahead of his party’s annual conference this weekend, Mr Eastwood said that despite lacklustre poll ratings, the SDLP hoped to secure two ministries in the next Executive.However, he refused rule out going into oppositionhe didn’t believe that it would be “a government truly working for the people”.In a wide-ranging interview, he described Doug Beattie as “a breath of fresh air within unionism”. While he was aghast at the UUP leader’s tweets, he respected how he had faced up to his mistakes, taken the heat and opened himself up to scrutiny in media interviews.Mr Eastwood also said he had no regrets about using parliamentary privilege to name Soldier F, who faced murder charges for his actions on Bloody Sunday.He said he was “giving a voice” to the people of Derry in a House of Commons that desperately needs to hear views from Northern Ireland other than the DUP’s.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Despite at times sharing similar policies with Sinn Fein, Mr Eastwood insisted the parties were in practice very dferent.“Sinn Fein are interested in themselves alone. They’re focused on what benefits them as a party, what improves their position, securing community jobs for their mates,” he said.“They’ve been at the top in Stormont since  and have failed to change the lives of working-class communities despite having their hands on the levers of power.“After  years, you’ve had your chance. Those who don’t deliver should be punished at the ballot box. “Sinn Fein are not outsiders. With the DUP, they are the political establishment in the North.”Mr Eastwood was unimpressed with Sinn Fein’s performance in the current Executive: “They talk a lot, but don’t seem to do much. What have they actually achieved “Nichola Mallon and Robin Swann have been the outstanding ministers in the Executive. I don’t see too many others that have done much.”The SDLP leader accused the DUP of pursuing a “destructive and unbelievably foolish course of action”y.He expects his party to improve on its  seats and % vote in the  Assembly election. He is hoping it will secure a similar vote to its  Westminster result of %.“We would hope to gain enough seats to have two ministers in the next executive,” Mr Eastwood said.“We are running to be in government. It’s in our DNA to be in government.”But he said he could not rule out going into opposition “ we think it’s a government that will do nothing for the people”.On just % in this week’s Irish News Institute of Irish Studies of University of Liverpool poll, the SDLP seems to have a steep hill to climbit is tomore MLAs. Successive LucidTalk polls for the Belfasthave put the party in fourth or fth position.“I think that too much attention is given to polls in Northern Ireland,” Mr Eastwood said“As a deeply ided society, it’s one of the hardest places to poll. You have five political parties within  to % of each other, so it’s complicated.“We are not blind to polls, but neither are we worried about them. We do our own research and we’re confident that we’re not on %.”Mr Eastwood said the DUP’s decision to collapse the Executive had polarised the political environment in a way that suited Sir Jeffrey Donaldson’s party and Sinn Fein.But the SDLP leader predicted it would not be a “pro- or anti-protocol” election.“In my office in Derry, people aren’t talking about the protocol. They’re worried about bills and hospital waiting lists. They’re annoyed at sluggish government.“There has been no response to the cost of living crisis by Stormont. In Scotland, the government is putting money into people’s bank accounts. Ours is doing nothing.”The SDLP leader said that in some constituencies, his party would be battling with Sir Jeffrey Donaldson’s for the last seat, “and that will create a dynamic which helps us”.He cited Strangford as its best chance of a gain, followed by Fermanagh and South Tyrone and West Belfast, “while there’s an outside chance we will be in the mix at the end in South Antrim”.The SDLP faces a tough battle to retain its seats in three constituencies. However, Mr Eastwood was “very confident” Pat Catney would be re-elected in Lagan Valley he said Dolores Kelly should “never be written off” in Upper Bann and he believed his party had “enough votes to keep our two seats in South Down”.The SDLP leader said he wouldn’t be advising voters who to transfer to. “There’ll be dferent considerations in dferent constituencies,” he said. He would like people “to vote progressively and for change”.AskedSDLP supporters should transfer to unionist candidates he said: “If a candidate is progressive, then there shouldn’t be community barriers to giving them a preference. In the polling booth, I have and will transfer across the community ide.”In the wake of Doug Beattie’s tweet scandal, Mr Eastwood said he had “failed the leadership test”.Askedthe UUP leader should have resigned, he replied: “What Doug did was wrong and dficult to understand, but there was something very powerful in his ability to face up to his mistakes and to take the heat.“I think in those circumstances, people are ready to forgive. I certainly don’t agree with Doug on everything, but I like him. I think he’s coming at things from a good place. He’s a breath of fresh air for unionism.”Mr Eastwood said it had been “very important” for him to name Soldier F in the Commons.“The Bloody Sunday families wanted him outed and I wanted my constituents’ voices heard,” he explained.“I received numerous death threats for it, some more sinister than others. That’s fine for me, but it was hard for my family.“I didn’t believe anything would happen to them, but you still worry when you’re away from home at nights.”Mr Eastwood insisted that his party had influence at Westminster: “Claire Hanna and I are not going to overturn an -seat majority, but it’s vital that we — along with Stephen Farry — are there and it’s not just the DUP being heard.”He said that would particularly be the casean Executive could not be formed after May’s election and direct rule was reintroduced.The potential partnership with Fianna Fail, which Mr Eastwood had championed, is clearly now dead in the water for the SDLP.  Asked about the possibility, he would say only that he was “in regular contact” with Fianna Fail and that the shared island unit had “come out of our conversations” with Micheal Martin.Claire Hanna had strongly opposed any merger. Effectively acknowledging it was totally off the agenda now, Mr Eastwood stressed: “The SDLP stands on its own two feet.“We’ve moved beyond old arguments. I work very well with Claire Hanna at Westminster and she’s part of the leadership team.”The SDLP leader also categorically ruled out ever personally seeking a dual mandate. title: visa and amazon announce worldwide payment agreement
story: Visa and Amazon have announced an agreement that allows customers to use Visa cards on Amazon sites worldwide without additional fees  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueVisa and Amazon have announced an agreement that allows customers to use Visa cards on Amazon sites worldwide without additional fees By Associated Press ReportersFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailVisa and Amazon have announced an agreement that will allow customers to use Visa cards on Amazon sites worldwide without additional fees.The companies also agreed to collaborate on product and technology initiatives for “innovative payment experiences”, Visa said on Thursday.Credit card fees have been a growing source of tension between Amazon and Visa.Last year, Amazon started charging customers in Australia and Singapore who use Visa credit cards a .% surcharge.Under the agreement, Amazon’s amazon site in Britain will no longer turn off Visa credit cards. Customers in Australia and Singapore will no longer pay the surcharge for using Visa.Last month, Amazon’s British website backed away from plans to stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in the UK, saying the two sides were talking.Amazon had announced the move in November, blaming “the high fees Visa charges for processing credit card transactions”.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive
